entry.title: Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed
entry.summary: The post Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics
entry.summary: Note: We did not receive enough responses from Hispanic or Black experts to be able to report expert views by race and ethnicity; this reflects the racial and ethnic makeup of the field. These groups‚Äô responses are incorporated into the general figures throughout. We also did not receive enough responses from experts working at nonprofits, [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This report is based on a pair of Pew Research Center surveys and a series of in-depth interviews. It draws on a nationally representative survey of U.S. adults who are members of the Center‚Äôs American Trends Panel (ATP), a survey of U.S.-based experts in artificial intelligence (AI) and 30 in-depth interviews with experts who participated [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Public and expert predictions for AI‚Äôs next 20 years
entry.summary: We explore how the public and experts anticipate potential positive and negative impacts of AI across key areas of life and society in the coming decades. The post 3. Public and expert predictions for AI‚Äôs next 20 years appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at¬†pewresearch.org/internet. Primary researchers Colleen McClain, Senior ResearcherBrian Kennedy, Senior ResearcherJeffrey Gottfried, Associate Director, Internet and Technology Research¬†Monica Anderson, Director, Internet and Technology Research¬†¬†¬†Giancarlo Pasquini, Research Associate¬† Research team Eileen Yam, Director, Science and Society ResearchAlec [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences
entry.summary: As AI becomes part of everyday life, we look at how the public and AI experts experience and view AI, including control of its role in their lives. The post 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence
entry.summary: These groups are far apart in their enthusiasm and predictions for AI, but both want more personal control and worry about too little regulation. The post How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: ‚ÄòEvery piece tells a story‚Äô: Bombs to beauty, from Gaza to Ukraine
entry.summary: What happens to bombs after they land? Some explode. Some don‚Äôt, leaving behind a deadly legacy of war, but now the remnants of conflict and devastation are being turned into wearable messages of peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Armed violence displaces thousands as cholera outbreak worsens
entry.summary: Ongoing violence in North and South Kivu in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to kill, injure and displace civilians, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Israeli military escalation in Syria, Nicaragua rights probe, South Sudan talks
entry.summary: The UN Special Envoy for Syria has condemned the repeated and intensifying military escalations by Israel in the country, including airstrikes that have caused civilian casualties.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief warns of increasing risk of atrocity crimes in Gaza
entry.summary: The recent killings of 15 medical personnel and humanitarian aid workers in Gaza raise further concerns over the commission of war crimes by the Israeli military, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN envoy urges international support for West Africa and the Sahel
entry.summary: In a briefing to the Security Council on Thursday, the UN Special Representative for West Africa and the Sahel painted a mixed picture of the region, which is facing a growing terrorist threat but also political progress and encouraging initiatives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar: UN chief calls for urgent access as quake toll mounts
entry.summary: The UN chief on Thursday called for immediate and unrestricted humanitarian access to Myanmar, where last week‚Äôs devastating earthquakes claimed over 3,000 lives and left millions in urgent need of aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: AI‚Äôs $4.8 trillion future: UN warns of widening digital divide without urgent action
entry.summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on course to become a $4.8 trillion global market by 2033 ‚Äì roughly the size of Germany‚Äôs economy ‚Äì but unless urgent action is taken, its benefits may remain in the hands of a privileged few, a new UN report warns.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan crisis: UN rights chief condemns extrajudicial killings in Khartoum
entry.summary: The fight for Sudan‚Äôs capital, Khartoum, likely involved widespread summary executions of civilians following its recent recapture by the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), UN human rights chief Volker T√ºrk¬†said¬†on Thursday.

entry.title: Who invented s‚Äômores? Forget the myths‚Äîthis is the real history
entry.summary:
Dorothy Christian Moore knew the rules when she climbed in the dark to the ship‚Äôs bridge. ‚ÄúThis is strictly forbidden,‚Äù she wrote as she crossed the Atlantic Ocean, ‚Äúand I hadn‚Äôt been there two minutes before someone seized me roughly from behind.‚Äù She explained to the officer her pursuit of the sunrise, and together they watched the blue horizon split into silver, then blaze to gold‚Äîlike so many campfires that would define her years in the United States.
She arrived the next morning at the invitation of the Girl Scouts to spend the summer of 1923 sharing her skills. Her stint as a volunteer in an officer‚Äôs hospital kitchen during World War I, feeding 150 men a day, had earned her the affectionate nickname ‚ÄúCookie.‚Äù After the war, she continued in public service as a leader in Girl Gu‚Ä¶

entry.title: How these two vitamin supplements could do more harm than good
entry.summary:
Fat-soluble vitamins, such as vitamin E photographed above, are stored in the body's fat reserves, which is why they have potential to accumulate to toxic levels. Fat-soluble vitamins are more likely to cause adverse effects if consumed in large doses. Here‚Äôs what the experts say about vitamin A and E.
Vitamins and supplements are a booming industry. And while there are many important supplements that benefit people with specific deficiencies or certain health conditions, research shows and experts agree that some synthetic vitamins could cause harms such as liver damage, hair loss, joint and muscle pain, and impaired vision.
"Everyone is always searching for that magic pill that will give them great health, but dietary supplements just aren't it because the benefits often don‚Ä¶

entry.title: The 'stork sisters' are saving one of India's largest and rarest birds
entry.summary:
Known locally as¬†hargila, the threatened Greater Adjutant stork has found a champion in an unlikely place: the Harglia Army,¬†a group of about 20,000 rural women in India turned conservationists. Since 2014, the women have worked tirelessly to give the storks a desperately needed reputational revamp.¬†
Once reviled as filthy, adjutants prey on fish, frogs, snakes, rats, and smaller birds like ducks, rummaging through landfills looking for carcasses (hargila translates to bone swallower). Its feeding habits cemented its reputation as unsanitary, a perception that led to a rapid population decline of the adjutant, one of the world‚Äôs largest and rarest storks. Native to¬†India's floodplains in Assam and Bihar, in 2023, it was recently listed as ‚Äúnear threatened‚Äù by the International Union f‚Ä¶

entry.title: Penguins are insanely resilient‚Äîand these explorers are revealing their secrets
entry.summary:
Borboroglu has been an Explorer since receiving the National Geographic/Buffett Award for Leadership in Conservation in 2018. Pablo ‚ÄúPopi‚Äù Garc√≠a Borboroglu and Bertie Gregory have been named the 2025 Rolex National Geographic Explorers of the Year.
As a boy growing up in Argentina‚Äôs Buenos Aires Province, Pablo ‚ÄúPopi‚Äù Garc√≠a Borboroglu was enchanted by his grandmother‚Äôs tales of her youthful visits to the teeming penguin colonies of Argentine Patagonia. He was a 19-year-old tour guide when he first glimpsed one, and it dawned on him then how important it was to share with others his sense of awe, inspiring them to protect penguins and their habitats.¬†
A hemisphere away, Bertie Gregory came to a similar realization as a teenage wildlife photographer roaming the English country‚Ä¶

entry.title: Myanmar quake: UN calls for urgent protection for vulnerable women and girls
entry.summary: Friday‚Äôs devastating earthquakes in Myanmar not only caused mass casualties and widespread destruction, they also deepened long-standing gender inequalities ‚Äì leaving millions of women and girls at heightened risk, UN aid agencies warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòAttacks on aid workers must end,‚Äô Security Council told
entry.summary: Two senior UN officials appealed in the Security Council on Wednesday for an end to attacks against humanitarians and personnel working for the global organization.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Accountability for missing persons is ‚Äòcrucial‚Äô: UN human rights chief
entry.summary: 2024 saw the highest increase in missing persons in at least two decades, with 56,559 new cases recorded, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross.

entry.title: Why Florida's greatest family attractions are in the wild
entry.summary:
The observation towers in the Everglades National Park are perfect for taking in Florida's natural beauty. America‚Äôs sunshine state is a natural playground, with wildlife sanctuaries and conservation-led attractions aimed at families.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Families know what to expect from a visit to Florida, right? Disney World, Universal Studios and other theme parks are the main reason for many visits to the southern state. Yet Florida has a lot more to offer kids on a stimulating, active and even educational family holiday. You can snorkel or try Snuba off the coast, kayak through mangrove channels inhabited by manatees, visit the holiday home of one of the world‚Äôs greatest inventors, explore the Everglades swamps, track dolphin‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the simple fork almost tore apart the fabric of society
entry.summary:
The dinner fork is one of the most common fixtures at tables worldwide‚Äîso ordinary, so unthreatening, that few give it a second thought. But for centuries, the fork was condemned as a symbol of decadence, moral decay, and social arrogance.
Throughout most of history, fingers were nature‚Äôs utensils. Knives sliced meat, spoons scooped broth, but only the hand completed the act of nourishment. The fork, however, was something else entirely. ‚ÄúThe introduction of the fork reflected and, at the same time, accelerated a series of profound changes in food culture and table habits,‚Äù says Lucia Galasso, a food anthropologist from Rome. It brought about a more controlled, refined eating process‚Äîone that not everyone welcomed.
The fork‚Äôs journey from forbidden instrument to universal utensil‚Ä¶

entry.title: These sea lions aren't 'demonic'‚Äîthey've been poisoned
entry.summary:
Rescuers capture a sick sea lion in Santa Barbara, California. Hundreds of animals have become ill from a neurotoxin, found in algae blooms, that causes concerning behavioral changes. Two beachgoers have been bitten. A common neurotoxin produced by algae blooms is making California sea lions more aggressive. Here‚Äôs why it has the power to change behavior‚Äîand the danger it poses.
¬†
RJ LaMendola, a 40-year-old photographer, was surfing north of Los Angeles last month when a sea lion charged at him and bit his backside through his wetsuit. The sea lion stalked LaMendola as he desperately tried to paddle to shore, keeping the board between himself and¬†the animal.¬†

entry.title: Here's why pro photographers obsess over this camera bag
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
For seven years, I relied on my trusty camera bag to accompany me to all the remote places around the world where I reported travel and adventure stories. Last year, it finally broke and I discovered that it had been discontinued. That sent me on an unexpectedly trying mission to find an alternative. There are plenty of camera bags, but as an adventure travel journalist and photographer, I couldn‚Äôt get just any bag.¬†
I needed a weather-resistant ca‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ancient walking trails are back‚Äîand you can hike them
The Louvre is a gastronomic journey‚Äîif you know where to look
In Fiji, these hotels put the guests to work (in a good way)
entry.summary: Tourism Fiji's new initiative is rooted in the local concept of loloma, meaning to act with generosity, driven by love, and aims to inspire visitors to help conserve and protect the local flora and fauna. From mangrove nurseries to manta ray protection, these 6 hotels invite guests to help protect the local land and animals. Fiji‚Äôs gin-bottle-blue waters, luminous sand, and riotously colorful rainforests have long made it a dream destination. But even paradise needs protection ‚Äî the archipelago faces significant threats from climate change, ranging from rising sea levels encroaching on low-lying habitats to coral bleaching damaging the reefs that sustain marine life and shield shorelines from erosion. That‚Äôs why hotels across Fiji are inviting guests to be p‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this the most beautiful bookstore in the world?
entry.summary:
Luigi Frizzo¬†was warned¬†that the property he was about to lease could be in a flood zone because of its proximity to the water and rising sea levels in in Venice, Italy. It actually sparked his decision to name his bookstore¬†Acqua Alta¬†(High Tide).
In addition to coming up with his bookshop's name, Frizzo also took proactive steps to create a flood-proof infrastructure plan to protect¬†more than¬†5,000 books, including first editions published more than a century ago.¬†He decided to store¬†hundreds of books¬†in bathtubs and¬†gondolas,¬†long¬†row boats¬†that have provided transportation through¬†Venice's¬†narrow canals since the 11th century.¬†
In case you didn't know, Acqua Alta¬†is located¬†less than a mile north of Piazza San Marco, the principal public square in Venice. It's easily flooded ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Archaeologists found another Egyptian royal tomb‚Äîbut whose is it?
entry.summary:
The discovery of the tomb of an ancient pharaoh‚Äîthe second report in as many months‚Äîleads a recent spate of archaeological finds from Egypt and casts new light on a formative period of the civilization along the Nile.
In December and January, a team of American and Egyptian archaeologists excavated the roughly 3,600-year-old tomb near the Abydos archaeological site, on the edge of the desert west of the Nile and about 20 miles northwest of the modern city of Luxor in southern Egypt. Egypt's antiquities ministry announced the find in a Facebook post last month.
But the name of the pharaoh who was once entombed there is unknown, as are many of the details about the dynasty of kings he belonged to.
"Egypt was broken apart into multiple rival kingdoms when these kings were rulin‚Ä¶

entry.title: The day that forced Americans to confront a hidden threat
entry.summary:
FBI agents lead Timothy McVeigh from the courthouse after he was charged with the April 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. McVeigh, who was convicted of the bombing that killed 168 people, wasn't a foreign agent but rather a homegrown terrorist with anti-government views. It‚Äôs been 30 years since Timothy McVeigh bombed the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, an attack that reawakened the nation to the dangers of domestic terrorism.
At 9:02 a.m. on April 19, 1995, a bomb ripped open the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City. The explosion took the lives of 168 people, including 19 young children. It would go down as one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in U.S. history.
It also forced Americans to grapple with an uncom‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why you should visit Mississauga‚ÄîCanada's lakeside city
entry.summary:
While Mississauga‚Äôs sleek yet modest skyline and expansive waterfront might not be as well known as the limelight-stealing attractions of neighbouring Toronto, this attractive city on the shores of Lake Ontario has plenty to offer. As home to the country‚Äôs largest airport, it serves as the entry point for many travellers to Canada, but there‚Äôs much to reward visitors who stick around, with more than 500 wildlife-filled parks, an international food scene and Niagara Falls just across the water, plus a vibrant schedule of year-round markets and festivals. Here‚Äôs what not to miss in Mississauga.
In the heart of the city, Riverwood Park‚Äôs 150 acres features curated gardens blooming with rhododendrons, as well as forests, wetlands and meadows hiding herons, sandpipers, hawks, owls an‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to travel in May
entry.summary:
May is the month that signals the start of summer in Europe‚Äôs coastal resorts. Summer is on the way, with Europe's beach resorts dusting off their sun loungers, marine life gathering for feeding seasons and a packed programme of seaside festivals and arts events around the world to tempt travellers.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Temperatures in Mediterranean, Aegean and Ionian waters start to rise, many of the region‚Äôs lidos and beach clubs open, and Ibiza's superclub season gets underway with big launch parties.
There are plenty of seaside arts festivals kicking off, too. Notably Brighton Festival (3-26 May 2025) in the UK ‚Äî a mega multi-arts event taking over the Sussex coastal city, with a programme large enough to warrant its own f‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lebanon: UN expresses deep concern over latest Israeli airstrikes, in call for restraint
entry.summary: The United Nations on Tuesday expressed deep concern over the latest escalation of violence in Lebanon, despite the fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah, following an Israeli airstrike in southern Beirut that reportedly killed four people ‚Äì including a woman ‚Äì and injured several others.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Surging violence as armed groups target civilians in the east, Human Rights Council hears
entry.summary: Civilians continue to bear the brunt of the violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) with 602 victims of extrajudicial or summary executions in North and South Kivu recorded over just two months, the¬†Human Rights Council heard on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan on brink of famine as fighting ravages Darfur, UN warns
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in Sudan is spiralling as rival militaries continue to battle for control of the country, with the UN expressing profound alarm on Monday over escalating hostilities, particularly in North Darfur.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres calls for greater equality and inclusion as world marks Autism Awareness Day
entry.summary: Although people with autism are making enormous contributions to societies across the globe, they still face significant challenges.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN-backed forum seeks to boost resilience of world‚Äôs Least Developed Countries
entry.summary: Policymakers, researchers, the private sector and other stakeholders are meeting in Zambia‚Äôs capital, Lusaka, over the next three days to chart a path toward sustainable development and resilience for the world‚Äôs Least Developed Countries (LDCs).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza aid worker killings: One humanitarian still missing in mass grave
entry.summary: UN humanitarians and partners on Tuesday expressed deep shock at the killing of 15 colleagues on duty in southern Gaza by Israeli forces whose¬†remains were recovered on Sunday from a shallow grave after a week-long rescue operation, noting that one worker is still missing.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar earthquake latest: Entire communities flattened, aid teams say
entry.summary: As the death toll continues to rise in Myanmar after last Friday's earthquake tragedy, UN humanitarians have been rushing to support severely deprived and traumatized victims, warning that the window for lifesaving response is closing.

entry.title: How to save money while traveling
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Travel can be rewarding, but it can also be expensive. The cost can ramp up when you factor in gear and supplies you may need for specialized excursions, like trekking or kayaking. If you do have to shop for an upcoming trip, it pays to be strategic.¬†
‚ÄúBuying affordable, high-quality, multipurpose travel gear means spending less money on products pre-trip,‚Äù says Sunny Fitzgerald, a travel writer who splits her time between Jordan, Costa Rica, and H‚Ä¶

entry.title: At these Alpine spas, ancient remedies have a modern twist
entry.summary:
At 95¬∞F, the air is charged with a tangerine tang as a man twists and whirls a towel like a whip, unleashing blasts of hot air to the beat of jungle drums. This is Aufguss: a multi-sensory sauna ritual that‚Äôs part purification, part fever-dream.
Deep in the Dolomites ‚Äî the UNESCO-capped mountains ‚Äî wellness has long been part of the landscape itself. Here, ancient remedies are reimagined with a contemporary twist and a touch of the surreal, all infused with the rugged spirit of the Alps.¬†
The journey begins in Bolzano, capital of South Tyrol and gateway to the Dolomites. A melting pot of Italian and German culture, locals toast beer and wine in Piazza Walther, savor boiled dumplings at Batzen H√§usl, and cycle down cobblestone streets beneath sweeping mountains. Its most famous ‚Ä¶

entry.title: See a different side of Ibiza with a stay in its historic capital
entry.summary:
Ibiza Town was founded by the Phoenicians in the seventh century. See another side of the Balearic Islands with a trip to Ibiza‚Äôs whitewashed capital, where winding streets lead to remnants of empires past.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Founded on the White Isle‚Äôs southeastern coast by seventh-century Phoenicians, Ibiza Town ‚Äî known to locals as Eivissa ‚Äî is one of Spain‚Äôs oldest cities. Over the centuries, Mediterranean tides brought countless conquerors to its shores, many of whom left their mark on Dalt Vila, the city‚Äôs fortified, UNESCO-listed old quarter. And yet, such is Ibiza‚Äôs beach-holiday and clubbing fame that its capital‚Äôs historical riches, along with its flourishing culinary scene and quietly bohemian energy, continue to fly u‚Ä¶

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This is the latest report in Pew Research Center‚Äôs ongoing investigation of the state of news, information and journalism in the digital age, a research program funded by The Pew Charitable Trusts, with generous support from the John S. and James [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 164 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Feb. 24 to March 2, 2025. A total of 5,123 panelists responded out of 5,737 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Most Americans Say They Are Tuned In to News About the Trump Administration
entry.summary: Far fewer are hearing about the administration‚Äôs relationship with the media than was the case early in President Donald Trump‚Äôs first term. The post Most Americans Say They Are Tuned In to News About the Trump Administration appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Would you stay at this lighthouse on a remote Tuscan island?
entry.summary:
Faro Capel Rosso is both a functioning lighthouse and a guesthouse. Play castaway on an Italian island, where you can spot whales from a stylish Tuscan retreat set in a working lighthouse.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This unique retreat ‚Äì a converted lighthouse on the southernmost tip of Giglio island ‚Äì comes with its own helipad. But for your average traveller, making pilgrimage to its remote setting is integral to its charm. Travel out to the Tuscan isthmus of Argentario for the ferry from Porto Santo Stefano, an hour across the turquoise Tyrrhenian to arrive in Giglio Port. Follow the island‚Äôs coastal road until it turns to a red sandy trail at Punta di Capel Rosso, where it‚Äôs a steep hike down through groves of cliff-clinging cactus t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Myanmar earthquake: Search and rescue efforts continue in race against time
entry.summary: The human toll of the earthquake which devastated central Myanmar continues to rise, UN humanitarians warned on Sunday, putting more pressure on nearly 20 million people who were already in need of aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Why this Greek island is perfect for families
entry.summary:
Cameo Island, part of the National Marine Park of Zakynthos, is connected to the mainland by a wooden bridge. Discover the dramatic caves, storied monasteries and hands-on activities that make the south of Zakynthos such a family-friendly Greek getaway.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A Greek island holiday will feature on many travellers‚Äô wish lists, but families may find themselves bewildered by choice ‚Äî there are more than 6,000 of them, with 227 being inhabited. Part of the Ionian archipelago and easily reached by a direct flight, mid-size Zakynthos ticks all the boxes ‚Äî its southern peninsulas of Keri and Vassilikos are particularly well-served by diverse landscapes and stellar beaches, rich (partly Venetian) history and varied activitie‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore the Maya ruins of Guatemala's Pet√©n department
entry.summary:
The fall of the ancient Maya civilisation came gradually ‚Äî as did the disappearance of its centres of power, each one slowly reclaimed by the creeping jungle. Mighty cities were lost for centuries, biding their time beneath thick drapes of vines and moss like dust sheets. In Guatemala, after the curtain was drawn back, hoards of artefacts eventually made their way to the National Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology in Guatemala City, one of the largest troves of Maya antiques. But other relics wound up in much smaller collections ‚Äî like the one I come across by chance on a small private island in Lake Pet√©n Itz√°, far from the capital in the country‚Äôs wild north.
I first spy the isle from the bigger, neighbouring island of Flores, home to a namesake port town. I‚Äôm in the city as a gate‚Ä¶

entry.title: Taste spring around the world with these 5 new cookbooks
entry.summary:
Clockwise from left: Monsoon by Asma Khan, Lugma by Noor Murad, Cook Korea! by Billy Law, La Cocina Vasca by Mar√≠a Jos√© Sevilla, Caribe by Keshia Sakarah These are the cookbooks to have this spring.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The third cookbook from Asma Khan ‚Äî chef and owner of London restaurant Darjeeling Express ‚Äî is split into six sections, one for each of the Bengali seasons: the familiar four, plus monsoon and dry season. Cooking this way is intuitive for Khan, who grew up eating seasonally in Kolkata, the capital of India‚Äôs West Bengal state. Starting with grishsho (summer), light dishes like courgette paratha give way to beef isthu (a mild beef stew) and pumpkin dal, before readers progress into the b√¥rsha (monsoon) and sh√¥rot ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to spend 4 days in St John's, Canada
entry.summary:
Find humongous humpbacks and pint-sized puffins at home among icebergs adrift in the Atlantic in Newfoundland and Labrador. Canada‚Äôs easternmost province beckons travellers to explore its wealth of seaboard towns, towering lighthouses and historic landmarks, as well as to experience its rich culture and heritage.
The province‚Äôs main gateway and largest city, St. John‚Äôs, is surprisingly close to London (with a flight time of roughly five hours), yet the city and the surrounding Avalon Peninsula are a world apart. For those who like to travel by road, a four-day itinerary encapsulates the best of this independently minded province. Come for the fish and chips and Celtic-tinged folk sessions, stay for the quirky delicacies, like iceberg-brewed lagers, and the time-honoured traditions suc‚Ä¶

entry.title: Looking beyond GDP to reach the Sustainable Development Goals
entry.summary: Countries should consider looking beyond Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, as the key measure of economic growth to achieve the ambitious Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), UN policymakers have suggested.

entry.title: Unlock the secrets of longevity in these destinations
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Longevity travel is one of the biggest trends of the year, as people¬†worldwide become ever more fascinated with living a¬†longer, fuller life. Many are spending significant sums, investing in state-of-the-art tests and biohacking treatments that¬†claim to help you extend your lifespan. But what if you could¬†live to 100 and still enjoy good health without the intervention of science or¬†tech?
Deep in the south of Japan, miles away from the mainland, lies the subtropical island of Okinawa. A slow-paced paradise hugged by pristine beaches, it‚Äôs home to a community of islanders that can teach us a thing or two about living well. Okinawa is one of the five original ‚ÄòBlue Zone‚Äô destinations, a handful of places where peopl‚Ä¶

‰ΩÜÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÊ≥¢ÂΩ¢Êñá‰ª∂Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†‰ªîÁªÜÊîæÂ§ßÁúãÔºå‰ªñÂ∞±ÊàêÊñπÂΩ¢ÁöÑ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ËøôËæπÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÁî®Âà∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁêÜÊÉ≥ÁöÑ‰ΩéÈÄöÊª§Ê≥¢Âô®Ôºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Áü©ÂΩ¢ËÑâÂÜ≤ÂáΩÊï∞ (Boxcar function) „ÄÇ ‰ªñÁªèËøáÂÇÖÈáåÂè∂ÂèòÊç¢‰ª•ÂêéÂèòÊàêËæõÊ†ºÂáΩÊï∞ (Sinc function)ÔºåËÄå sinc ÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÈáçÂª∫Êó∂Êúâ‰∏™Áº∫ÁÇπÔºåÈÇ£Â∞±ÊòØÂú®Â•àÂ•éÊñØÁâπÈ¢ëÁéáÁöÑÈÉ®ÂàÜ‰ºöÊúâ‰∏™Â§ßÁ∫¶ 4 dB ÁöÑË°∞Âáè( sinc(1/2) = sin(œÄ/2)/(œÄ/2)=1/(œÄ/2) = 2/œÄ Ôºå20log(2/œÄ) = -3.92 dB) „ÄÇ ËØ∑ÁïôÊÑèÂú®‰ø°Âè∑È¢ÜÂüü sinc x = sin (œÄx)/(œÄx)ÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊòØÊï∞Â≠¶ËØæ‰∏äÂ≠¶ÁöÑ sinc x = sin (x)/x

entry.title: Haiti reaches ‚Äòyet another crisis point‚Äô as gangs tighten their grip
entry.summary: The UN human rights chief sounded the alarm on Thursday over the rapidly deteriorating situation in Haiti, calling it a ‚Äúcatastrophe‚Äù fuelled by gang violence, widespread impunity and a political process that is hanging by a thread.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Despite renewed conflict in eastern DR Congo, protection for civilians is paramount: Keita
entry.summary: As the conflict in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has intensified in recent months, the UN peacekeeping mission, MONUSCO, has been working to protect civilians - including in areas under the control of the Rwandan-backed M23 armed group in North Kivu province.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tens of millions risk starvation as funding cuts deepen crises in DR Congo: WHO, WFP
entry.summary: Sharply declining aid could force tens of millions across the globe who rely on food aid into extreme hunger and starvation, the World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòPerfect storm‚Äô in South Sudan demands urgent action, says Guterres
entry.summary: Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres warned on Friday of a rapidly deteriorating crisis in South Sudan, calling for urgent dialogue, the immediate release of detained officials and renewed commitment to the 2018 peace agreement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 47 million health workers and advocates call for cleaner air to curb pollution deaths
entry.summary: Over 50 countries, cities, and organizations pledged new commitments on Thursday to tackle air pollution, protect public health, and help halve its deadly impacts by 2040 ‚Äì a goal backed by a petition from 47 million health professionals, patients and advocates demanding clean air be made a public health priority.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Acts of war bear hallmarks of atrocity crimes, warn UN humanitarians
entry.summary: Lifesaving supplies in Gaza continue to run dangerously low, nearly four weeks into the total aid blockade and deadly bombardment of the enclave by Israel, UN humanitarians said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN teams ramp up response to deadly quake in Myanmar and Thailand
entry.summary: Amid reports of hundreds dead or missing following a 7.7 magnitude earthquake with its epicentre in central Myanmar, UN teams in the region are ‚Äúresponding fast‚Äù, said UN relief chief Tom Fletcher on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Extreme weather impacts cascading ‚Äòfrom the Andes to the Amazon‚Äô
entry.summary: Extreme weather and climate impacts had a damaging toll on Latin America and the Caribbean last year, resulting in dying glaciers, record-breaking hurricanes, debilitating drought and deadly floods, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said in a new report on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tariffs: Job protectors or trade killers?
entry.summary: The word ‚Äútariff‚Äù has been catapulted from the business pages to the headlines over the last few months, as major economies impose or threaten them on other nations. But tariffs are not just a blunt weapon to be used in geopolitical brinkmanship: they can, if used effectively, help poorer countries develop their economies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Fast fashion fuelling global waste crisis, UN chief warns
entry.summary: Fast fashion is accelerating an environmental catastrophe, with the equivalent of one garbage truck‚Äôs worth of clothing either incinerated or sent to landfill every second, the UN chief warned on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN humanitarians flag impact on children of return to war
entry.summary: The UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) issued a warning on Thursday over the terrible impact on youngsters of renewed Israeli bombardment and the total aid blockade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Armed groups install ‚Äòparallel administration‚Äô in DR Congo, Security Council hears
entry.summary: Armed groups affiliated with Rwanda-backed M23 rebels in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) have continued to expand their¬†control in North and South Kivu ‚Äì setting their sights on more territorial gains.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: Displacement figures fall for first time
entry.summary: For the first time in nearly two years of brutal conflict the number of Sudanese internally displaced during nearly two years of brutal conflict between rival militaries has fallen, the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Record numbers face acute or emergency hunger
entry.summary: A record¬†27.7 million people are in the grip of acute hunger in¬†the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid ongoing conflict linked to massive displacement and rising food prices,¬†global food security experts warned on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights body sounds the alarm over South Sudan crisis
entry.summary: The UN Commission on Human Rights in South Sudan issued an alert on Thursday over the the rapidly escalating crisis in the country, calling for urgent coordinated action to protect civilians and preserve the 2018 peace deal that ended five years of civil war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Salone love
entry.summary: A playful collage of audio interviews captures candid and revealing reflections on love, sex and marriage in Sierra Leone - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: How Kerala got rich
entry.summary: Fifty years ago it was one of India‚Äôs poorest states, now it is now one of the richest. How did Kerala do it? - by Tirthankar Roy & K Ravi Raman Read at Aeon

entry.title: How Two Graduate Reporters Exposed a System Used to Hide Police Officer Misconduct
entry.summary: Two reporters, nominated for the 2025 Goldsmith Prize, spent years investigating legal agreements in California that hide police officers' past misconduct from the public.

entry.title: Where to eat the best lobster roll in Boston
entry.summary: Hailing from Massachusetts, the lobster roll has been a popular snack with locals for generations. Visitors to Boston can try it in its place of origin, with the city's restaurants offering showstopping versions of this legendary sandwich.

entry.title: See how Muslims celebrate Eid al-Fitr around the world
entry.summary: From beachside prayers in Senegal to colorful festivals in Pakistan, these pictures show the many ways that Muslims observe the end of the holy month of Ramadan.

entry.title: Don‚Äôt paddle out without these key kayak accessories
entry.summary: The right extras, from grippy gloves to an insect repelling sunhat, can step up your next adventure.

entry.title: A space telescope just found a treasure trove of galaxies
entry.summary: Euclid, a European space telescope, just captured 26 million galaxies to reveal the secrets of the dark universe.

entry.title: Scientists want to poison mosquitos‚Äîwith human blood
entry.summary: Low doses of a drug already approved for treating rare genetic conditions in humans kills mosquitoes dead. Scientists say it could be a valuable new tool in the fight against disease.

entry.title: Methodology

The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Judaism, or remained Jewish since childhood, in the U.S. and Israel. The post 6. Religious switching into and out of Judaism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Religious switching into and out of Hinduism
entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Hinduism, or remained Hindu since childhood, in four countries. The post 5. Religious switching into and out of Hinduism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Religious switching into and out of Buddhism
entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Buddhism, or remained Buddhist since childhood, in six countries. The post 3. Religious switching into and out of Buddhism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Religious switching into and out of Islam
entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Islam, or remained Muslim since childhood, in 13 countries. The post 4. Religious switching into and out of Islam appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Religious switching into and out of the religiously unaffiliated group
entry.summary: Read about where religiously unaffiliated populations have had the largest net gains, and how those who've joined the "nones" identified previously. The post 2. Religious switching into and out of the religiously unaffiliated group appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Religious switching into and out of Christianity
entry.summary: Read about where Christianity has had the largest net losses, and how those who've left Christianity now identify religiously. The post 1. Religious switching into and out of Christianity appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Around the World, Many People Are Leaving Their Childhood Religions
entry.summary: In many places surveyed, 20% or more of all adults have left their childhood religious group. Christianity and Buddhism have had especially large losses. The post Around the World, Many People Are Leaving Their Childhood Religions appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Biological weapons ‚Äòmust not only be unthinkable but also impossible‚Äô
entry.summary: The world came together 50 years ago to ban biological weapons and in today‚Äôs volatile geopolitical climate we can ill-afford to let this moral safeguard ‚Äúerode‚Äù,¬†the UN‚Äôs¬†High Representative for Disarmament Affairs said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN calls for immediate ceasefire as South Sudan edges closer to renewed civil war
entry.summary: The UN Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) on Wednesday called for an immediate end to hostilities and urgent dialogue between the country‚Äôs leaders to prevent a relapse into civil war, as violence escalates around the capital city.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Rights chief deplores deadly army strikes on North Darfur market
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has again called for greater protection of civilians in war-torn Sudan following deadly army airstrikes in North Darfur earlier this week.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN welcomes Black Sea talks, warns of worsening humanitarian crisis in Ukraine
entry.summary: The United Nations on Wednesday welcomed recent diplomatic talks involving Russia, Ukraine and the United States in Saudi Arabia, calling an agreement on freedom of navigation and security in the Black Sea a crucial step for global food security.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòRenewables are renewing economies‚Äô, UN chief tells top climate forum
entry.summary: Ministers from 40 countries met on Wednesday at the first major climate forum of 2025 to discuss progress in renewable energy generation and the rising toll of inaction over rising temperatures.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Pact for the Future: Countries urged to translate pledges into action
entry.summary: UN Member States met on Wednesday for the first of three key meetings to advance a global agreement that pledges concrete actions to achieve a safer, more peaceful, sustainable and inclusive world for generations to come.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deadly impacts of childhood stunting can be prevented, WFP insists
entry.summary: Childhood stunting from malnutrition is a global but preventable problem if adequate investment can be found, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Wednesday, amid chronic funding shortages that threaten essential feeding programmes.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: Ten Years of War, a Lifetime of Loss
entry.summary: Marking a decade of war in Yemen, Othman Belbeisi, Regional Director for Middle East and North Africa at the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM), highlights the resilience of its people, the deepening humanitarian crisis, and the urgent need for global action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: No aid has reached war-torn enclave for more than three weeks
entry.summary: It has now been three and a half weeks since Israel imposed a complete blockade on all aid into Gaza, despite daily efforts by UN humanitarians to secure fresh access, they said in an¬†update from the shattered enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Can renewable energy survive climate change?
entry.summary: As droughts reduce hydropower and clouds dim solar output around the world, experts say meteorology and climate science must be at the heart of the energy transition.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 7 wild herbs you can forage in the UK
entry.summary: The UK‚Äôs green spaces are bursting with plants that add fascinating flavours to dishes. You just have to know what can be eaten ‚Äî and where to look.

entry.title: Why raw pet food isn't worth the risk
entry.summary:
A Maine Coon cat enjoys mealtime. Four house cats have died from H5N1 in cases linked to raw pet food, and experts say it‚Äôs not worth the risk.  A recent case of bird flu was linked to a cat's raw food diet. Experts stress there are other health risks, too.
Pet owners on TikTok who feed their cats and dogs raw food regularly show off their¬†colorful bowls, full of uncooked meats, organs, heads, feet, or bones.¬†
The $3.1 billion global raw pet food industry has always been controversial, since the food contains animal protein that hasn‚Äôt been cooked or heated enough to kill germs. But a recent link to bird flu is sounding a new alarm.¬†¬†
In December, a pet food company recalled a batch of its raw turkey frozen food after it¬†tested positive for H5N1, the highly deadly bi‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 cruises for foodies and wine lovers
entry.summary:
Some of the best food and wine cruises of 2025 include chef-led demonstrations, wine tastings, culinary classes, and more. Sail through the heart of the Pacific Northwest wine region. Sip wine on a river cruise through Bordeaux. These itineraries offer something for everyone.
When it comes to cruising, there‚Äôs a style, ship, and itinerary for everyone. Long gone are the days of massive buffets and sub-par dining. Cruise ships are now culinary beacons where guests can try new cuisines on and off the vessel. Every year, it seems the wine and culinary cruise options keep improving. Some of the best itineraries in 2025 include wine tasting on a river cruise through Bordeaux, sailing through the heart of the Columbia and Snake rivers for regional wine tastings, and cruising around the M‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in the Cotswolds, England's rural getaway
entry.summary:
From renowned produce to quintessential rural charm, the Cotswolds is the perfect English country getaway. The bucolic region in southwest England is home to some of the country‚Äôs most characterful accommodation, from charming pubs with rooms to retro-themed manor houses.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Cotswolds fulfils every picture of rural England you might care to conjure. Pretty villages of ancient stone houses curl around country lanes, with low hills rolling between. Handsome market towns brim with antique shops and coaching inns. Sweeping over six counties in the south west, the region was made rich in the Middle Ages by the wool trade, and retains an air of unruffled, comfortable respectability. The Cotswolds‚Äô quality produce ha‚Ä¶

author.name: Amanda Canning, George Clode, Sam Kemp, Angela Locatelli, Georgia Stephens, Orla Thomas

entry.title: A guide to Denver‚Äôs famed Red Rocks Amphitheatre
entry.summary: From Bono and Bonnie Raitt to The Beach Boys and The Beatles, world-class performances are part and parcel of the small sandstone outcrop on the edge of Colorado's Rocky Mountain foothills. Set in a red landscape of high-desert and sheer cliffs 15 miles from Denver, the 9,525-capacity Red Rocks Amphitheatre has won Pollstar‚Äôs award for best outdoor venue so many times that the award was renamed the 'Red Rocks Award'. And while Red Rocks found fame in the 20th century as a music venue, the area‚Äôs storied past spans millennia. Though nothing can compare to catching a live show, paying a visit to Red Rocks in the daytime offers a whole other experience, with the surrounding Red Rocks Park offering 738 acres of spectacular mountain scenery, ripe for exploring on foot, mountain bike or horse. Y‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why are so few African safaris Black-owned?
entry.summary:
A riverside lunch at Zambezi Sands in Zimbabwe‚Äôs Zambezi National Park highlights the hospitality of Batoka Africa, one of the few Black-owned safari companies on the continent. Founded by Vimbai Masiyiwa, Batoka is part of a growing effort to ensure local communities‚Äînot just international tourists‚Äîbenefit from wildlife tourism. While local ownership is growing, Black entrepreneurs remain rare in the billion-dollar safari industry. These trailblazers are pushing for change.
Vimbai Masiyiwa was on a family safari in Zimbabwe‚Äôs Victoria Falls National Park when a guide made an offhand remark that stuck with her. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs a lot more beautiful when we get to the lodge,‚Äù the guide said. The comment‚Äîmeant to gloss over the poverty outside‚Äîleft Masiyiwa unsettled. Why was the r‚Ä¶

entry.title: This bizarre dinosaur has something in common with modern sloths
entry.summary:
Therizinosaurs were some of the strangest dinosaurs of all time. Descended from carnivores, the prehistoric reptiles were plant-eaters and had fuzzy feathered bodies, small heads with peg-like teeth in their jaws, bulbous stomachs that acted like fermenting vats for heaps of vegetation, and impressively large claws on each of their hands. Their build and claws have drawn comparisons to sloths, but some of these reptiles stood over 13 feet tall and weighed more than five tons. Now paleontologists have uncovered a therizinosaur that stands out even among its unusual relatives‚Äîbecause it‚Äôs missing a finger.¬†
Described in the journal iScience today, the new dinosaur comes from rocks in Mongolia‚Äôs Gobi Desert that are over 90 million years old. Back in 2012, paleontologists from the Mongol‚Ä¶

entry.title: Migrant deaths in Asia hit record high in 2024, UN data reveals
entry.summary: The year 2024 marked the deadliest on record for migrants in Asia, with at least 2,514 lives lost along the region‚Äôs perilous migration routes, according to new data from the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM).

entry.summary: The UN human rights office (OHCHR) expressed major concern on Tuesday following the detention of at least 92 people by the Turkish authorities over the past week, including Istanbul‚Äôs mayor, Ekrem ƒ∞mamoƒülu, who has been charged with corruption and removed from office.

entry.title: Niger: Mosque attack which killed 44 should be ‚Äòwake-up call‚Äô, says rights chief
entry.summary: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker T√ºrk on Tuesday condemned the recent attack on a mosque in Kokorou village, in western Niger, in which at least 44 worshippers were killed and 20 injured.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòFragility and hope‚Äô mark new era in Syria amid ongoing violence and aid struggles
entry.summary: UN Special Envoy for Syria Geir Pedersen briefed the Security Council on Tuesday, pointing to the devastating violence on the coast earlier this month, which marked a grim new chapter in Syria‚Äôs fragile transition to a lasting peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Crimes of the transatlantic slave trade ‚Äòunacknowledged, unspoken and unaddressed‚Äô
entry.summary: The transatlantic slave trade may have ended centuries ago but its legacy is ever present, the UN Secretary-General said on Tuesday, marking the International Day of Remembrance for its victims.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid operations stretched to the limit in Burundi by ongoing DR Congo crisis
entry.summary: With thousands fleeing violence in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) across the border into Burundi, aid operations are stretched to the limit, the World Food Programme (WFP)¬†said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: One in two children severely malnourished after 10 years of war
entry.summary: In Yemen, a decade of conflict has proved catastrophic for the country‚Äôs children living under the threat of airstrikes and staggeringly high malnutrition rates, the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Decades of progress in reducing child deaths and stillbirths at risk, UN warns
entry.summary: The number of children around the world dying before their fifth birthday stands at a record low ‚Äì but this achievement is under threat due to a chronic lack of investment in routine humanitarian work and interventions, the head of the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF), said on Tuesday.

entry.title: How to sleep better while traveling
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Getting enough sleep can be a real challenge, even on a good day. Quality sleep can be even harder to achieve when you‚Äôre traveling. Indeed, only one in three travelers report sleeping well.¬†
‚ÄúTravel is often about new experiences and environments, which is great for the soul and terrible for the body, particularly the sleeping body,‚Äù says Erica Huss, a wellness expert and host of the podcast All Too Well. ‚ÄúSleep thrives on routine and consistency,‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to travel better: a beginner's guide to sustainable travel
entry.summary:
In Europe, where many trains are electric, the emissions from rail travel can be as much as 10 times less than flying. Sustainable, green, responsible ‚Äî planet-friendly ways to explore the world are more popular than ever but how do you start to make better decisions when you travel? The first step is to understand what sustainable travel is and why it‚Äôs important.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sustainable travel is about travelling in a way that‚Äôs sensitive to the climate and nature emergencies while ensuring that the wellbeing of the places we visit gain long-term benefit from us travelling there. It‚Äôs a balancing act between maximising the positives of travel while reducing or eliminating the negatives.
The concentration of carbon‚Ä¶

entry.title: Startling Antarctic sea creatures found beneath huge iceberg
entry.summary:
On January 13, when an iceberg the size of Chicago broke away from Antarctica‚Äôs immense George VI Ice Shelf, scientists in a nearby research vessel did something nobody had ever done. They sailed to look at the seafloor that had suddenly been exposed, like lifting the world‚Äôs biggest rock to see what critters lay underneath.¬†
Life is almost everywhere in the oceans, from the sunlit-bathed shallows to the pitch-black, sometimes volcanic depths. The research team aboard the Schmidt Ocean Institute‚Äôs R/V¬†Falkor (too)¬†ship were confident they‚Äôd find animals at their destination. But they were shocked at the explosion of life they discovered‚Äîa forest of sponges, giant sea spiders, icefish, octopuses, huge corals, anemones, and ethereal deep-sea jellyfish.

entry.title: 8 spectacular places in the U.S. to see spring flowers in bloom
entry.summary:
The Cascade Volcanic Mountain Range looms behind a field of tulips in Washington's Skagit Valley. From blooms dotting desert cacti to rows of bright pink cherry trees, here's where to see this spring's best flower displays.
With daylight stretching longer and outdoor temperatures ticking upward, spring is in the air. Plants across the United States are quickening their growth, sprouting leaves and flowers as they revive the landscape. Spring will provide chances to admire the colorful transformation. Below are a few of the best places and times to witness the dramatic beauty of flowers in bloom.
Cherry trees in Washington, D.C.
Peak bloom: March, April
Each spring, the U.S. capital hosts the National Cherry Blossom Festival. Across three and a half weeks, 1.5 million‚Ä¶

entry.title: Guterres to reduce UN aid ‚Äòfootprint‚Äô inside Gaza following ceasefire collapse
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Monday took the ‚Äúdifficult decision‚Äù to reduce the aid operation inside the Gaza Strip following the resumption of deadly Israeli airstrikes ‚Äì but pledged that ‚Äúthe UN is not leaving‚Äù the enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudan on the brink of civil war, top UN official warns
entry.summary: South Sudan is teetering on the brink of a return to full-scale civil war as violence escalates and political tensions deepen, the head of the UN Mission in the country (UNMISS) warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: Staff members of the United Nations around the world who are recruited locally are ‚Äúparticularly vulnerable‚Äù to detention and should be released and allowed to go home according to the UN Secretary-General, Ant√≥nio Guterres.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt cut the aid‚Äô: Insecurity worsens for stateless Rohingya, says UNHCR‚Äôs Grandi
entry.summary: The plight of Myanmar‚Äôs ethnic Rohingya is intensifying almost eight years since hundreds of thousands fled persecution and sought shelter in Bangladesh, the UN said on Monday, in an appeal for $934.5 million to help them.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN peace missions strained, with trust ‚Äòin short supply‚Äô and widening divisions
entry.summary: United Nations peace operations are facing mounting challenges as conflicts become more protracted, geopolitical divisions widen and transnational threats multiply, Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòRacism requires ignorance‚Äô: How art and culture can help end racial discrimination
entry.summary: Despite significant progress over the years, the fight against racism and racial discrimination remains as urgent as ever.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UNAIDS chief warns of ‚Äòreal surge‚Äô in deaths without US funding
entry.summary: Amid continuing uncertainty about the impact of deep US funding cuts to humanitarian work worldwide, the head of the UN agency coordinating the fight against HIV-AIDS warned that an addition 6.3 million people will die in the next four years, unless support is reinstated.

entry.title: Phil Rosenthal on the people, places and dishes that have shaped his life
entry.summary: Phil‚Äôs European live tour is taking place until 19 April. The writer, producer and host of Somebody Feed Phil talks about eating ants in Tokyo, the legacy of Anthony Bourdain and the best shawarma he‚Äôs ever had. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). I was 17 when I had garlic for the first time. I always equate it to The Wizard of Oz, when Dorothy opens the door and the movie is then in colour. My parents were German immigrants, so we ate old-world German-style cuisine. Things like beef stew, chicken schnitzel, potatoes‚Ä¶ there was zero spice. Even when we ordered Chinese food, once every three months, it was always the blandest thing on the menu. It wasn‚Äôt until I left their house that I had food with flavour. My parents were fantastic in ev‚Ä¶

entry.title: 6 ways to explore Malta
entry.summary:
With its Neolithic history and distinctive limestone landscapes, Malta may seem a destination drawn from the past. But if this resilient archipelago has learnt anything from its numerous occupations, it‚Äôs to adapt. On the islands of Malta, Gozo and Comino, centuries-old forts and grand historic palaces now sit side-by-side with modern fine dining restaurants and sleek waterfront promenades. Travellers today are beckoned to explore Malta‚Äôs varied dive sites, hike through otherworldly landscapes or observe the host of international talent set to take the stage at the islands‚Äô assorted year-round festivals. With so many experiences to choose from, here are six not to miss.
Malta‚Äôs 300 days of sunshine a year mean the islands are ideal for outdoor activity ‚Äî even in the winter, cris‚Ä¶

entry.title: Investigating Clandestine Gold Mines, Deforestation, and Corporate Misconduct: The Reporter Who Made the Amazon His Beat
entry.summary: Hyury Potter is one of the leading environmental investigative journalists in Brazil. A freelance reporter, he recently won the Pulitzer Center's Breakthrough Journalism Award.

entry.title: This restaurant is Istanbul's trendiest‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At Istanbul restaurant Turk, Turkey‚Äôs first and only to have been awarded two Michelin stars, diners are introduced to the breadth and depth of Turkish cuisine. The country‚Äôs rich culinary heritage, diverse landscapes and cornucopia of ingredients inform creative dishes, which interpret this cultural and geographic influence through a modern lens.
The restaurant‚Äôs opening was something of a homecoming for chef Fatih Tutak. After a stint cooking in Bangkok, he returned to Turkey in 2019, embarking on a fresh discovery of his country and its cuisine, before launching his own establishment, Turk. ‚ÄúI had to find my own way of expressing myself and my home country‚Äôs food,‚Äù Tutak says.
(Related: these are the best r‚Ä¶

entry.title: Discover 5 of Louisiana's most iconic dishes
entry.summary: Being so uniquely Louisianan, the world-class dishes created in this Southern state are nearly impossible to define simply as American. The cuisine here reflects a varied tapestry of cultures, with the influence of France, Spain, West Africa, the Caribbean, Germany, Italy and Native Americans woven into its distinct recipes. In the west, you have Cajun country, an area populated by Acadians originally from French-speaking Canada. In the north, Southern-style home cooking is the order of the day. Then, there‚Äôs the Creole influence in the lively city of New Orleans. Wherever you head, many dishes are dominated by a slow-cooked roux, and the ‚Äòholy trinity‚Äô, a mixture of onions, peppers and celery ‚Äî Louisiana‚Äôs answer to the mirepoix (a base of diced vegetables). Discover this and much more of‚Ä¶

entry.title: 3-week Gaza aid ban ‚Äòcollective punishment‚Äô: UNRWA chief
entry.summary: The tight Israeli blockade of humanitarian supplies is pushing Gaza closer to an acute hunger crisis, Philippe Lazzarini, the head of the UN agency for Palestine refugees (UNRWA), said on Sunday.

entry.title: Mind your language: The battle for linguistic diversity in AI
entry.summary: For two years, one international organization under the umbrella of the UN has been leading a relentless campaign in the corridors of global digital diplomacy. Its mission? To bring linguistic diversity to English-dominated artificial intelligence.

entry.title: Why the Croatian island Braƒç is perfect for family getaways
entry.summary:
Braƒç‚Äôs main port town Supetar hosts a historic harbour with a busy promenade. The island of Braƒç is home to arguably the best beach on Croatia‚Äôs Dalmatian coast, along with crowd-pleasing local cuisine, gentle hikes and island-hopping opportunities that will keep families well entertained.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Just a short ferry-hop from the city of Split, Braƒç was put on the map by its extraordinary Zlatni Rat beach ‚Äî a giant tongue of pebbles that shifts with the tides and winds, making it a remarkable natural phenomenon. But this small Adriatic island is also ideally located for island-hopping, watersports, pootling around in characterful stone villages and active days out to mountain lookouts and along coastal hiking trail‚Ä¶

entry.title: Fish are once again spinning to death in the Florida Keys
entry.summary:
Dead sawfish washed up on beaches in the Florida Keys last year during a bizarre event where dozens of fish species began exhibiting an odd spinning behavior. Now, sawfish and others are starting to exhibit the behavior again. After nine months, the strange behavior that claimed the lives of endangered sawfish is back. Here‚Äôs what we know about what‚Äôs causing it.
A bizarre fish behavior has resurfaced in the Florida Keys, and scientists are working diligently to uncover the cause and its potential long-term effects.
In fall 2023, fish and rays were seen spinning in circles and swimming erratically. Critically endangered smalltooth sawfish would thrash back and forth and began washing up dead on beaches. The unusual phenomenon affected over 80 species, including snapper, bull s‚Ä¶

entry.title: West Africa Media Excellence Conference and Awards (WAMECA)
These stunts aren‚Äôt just magic tricks‚Äîthey‚Äôre acts of faith
entry.summary:
When Pallaniyammal Sanmugam was pregnant with her second son, her gynecologist advised she would have to undergo a cesarean section. Believing a vaginal delivery would be safer for both her and her baby, Sanmugam prayed to the Hindu god Karthikeya, promising that if she delivered a healthy baby through vaginal delivery, she would express her gratitude by piercing a trident through her body during Panguni Uthiram, a Hindu festival where devotees pierce their bodies with spikes, rods, and needles to pay respects to the god and thank him for fulfilled wishes. Soon, Sanmugam‚Äôs wish, too, was fulfilled.¬†
‚ÄúThe following year, I had a trident pierced through my abdomen. I‚Äôve done it 13 times so far, and each time, I‚Äôve received what I‚Äôd asked for. If my body cooperates, I‚Äôll do it at least t‚Ä¶

entry.title: How you can change your body's threshold for pain
entry.summary:
Pain likely began as a curious evolutionary advantage, helping organisms react to injury quickly and escape while also teaching them to avoid similarly harmful situations in the future.
Nowadays, most humans would go to great lengths to avoid feeling pain. But there are some who dedicate their lives to conquering the sensation, pushing their minds and bodies beyond typical physical limits to achieve dangerous, hair-raising feats.¬†
It‚Äôs this complex relationship with pain and endurance that renowned magician David Blaine explores in his new documentary series, David Blaine Do Not Attempt. Traveling the world in search of the extraordinary, Blaine discovers how performance can reinvent fear and influence our perception of pain.
David Blaine Do Not Attempt premieres on National‚Ä¶

entry.title: Scientists reveal a hidden world beneath Antarctica's ice where rivers flow uphill
entry.summary:
Antarctica‚Äôs massive ice sheet¬†looks flat. Although the continent‚Äôs expansive layer of ice¬†rises 13,400 feet above sea level near its center, the gentle slopes of that dome are imperceptible to the human eye.
But below that mile-thick ice lies something surprising: a landscape of steep mountains and valleys, traversed by meandering rivers. Those rivers could play a decisive role in how the ice sheet responds to unprecedented warmth.
Scientists now predict that as Antarctica‚Äôs ice sheet melts and thins over the next few decades, those hidden rivers will grow, jump their banks,¬†and shift onto new flow paths. This could destabilize large coastal glaciers that control the rate of sea level rise.
‚ÄúThe changes¬†are pretty drastic,‚Äù says Christine Dow, a glacial hydrologist at the U‚Ä¶

As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Today‚Äôs waterproof speakers have evolved significantly over the last few years. These innovative options are more durable than their predecessors and pack a powerful audio punch. They can be a great addition to travelers too, whether you‚Äôre planning a beach or lakeside getaway.¬†
‚ÄúWaterproof wireless Bluetooth speakers are an insurance policy for active people,‚Äù says Erin Lawrence, a tech and gadget reviewer and former journalist, based in Canada. ‚Äú‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the Mediterranean diet really is the healthiest
entry.summary:
Even if you‚Äôre not a fan of hummus, tabouli, or olives, it‚Äôs worth giving the Mediterranean diet a chance. Why? Because when it comes to the hierarchy of healthy eating patterns, the Mediterranean diet consistently comes out on top.
In 2025, U.S. News and World Report ranked it #1 overall, as well as giving it first place as the best diet for mental health, for healthy eating, for inflammation, for gut health and for being the easiest diet to follow. It‚Äôs delicious and nutritious, and consuming it is associated with a variety of health benefits. It is also easy to follow and sustainable for the long haul. And you don‚Äôt need to live in a Mediterranean country or even leave home to adhere to the eponymous diet or reap its benefits.
(What foods you really need to eat to reduce infla‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why penguin poop makes krill swim for their lives
entry.summary:
New research suggests that the presence of penguin poop causes krill to lose their appetite, among other behaviors. A new study shows that the mere presence of poop prompted the crustaceans to launch into evasive maneuvers.
Krill are like the popcorn shrimp of the Southern Ocean‚Äîeveryone from whales and seals to fish and penguins wants a bite.
But according to a new study, these translucent, pinkie finger-sized crustaceans aren‚Äôt as helpless as you might think.
(Life in Antarctica relies on a shrinking supply of krill.)
In Antarctica‚Äôs Palmer Station lab, scientists put wild-caught krill through a series of tests to see if they could identify the presence of a predator‚Äîin this case, Ad√©lie penguins‚Äîby squirting a slurry of penguin poop into the crustaceans‚Äô tanks. Be‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 places to see wildlife in the U.S. this spring
entry.summary:
In Hallo Bay, brown bears graze on sedge grass in Alaska's Katmai National Park, while outdoor enthusiasts watch at a safe distance. From wild ponies in Virginia to bison in Yellowstone, here are seven wildlife-rich destinations‚Äîand tips on how to be a responsible tourist.
Spring is a magical time to witness wildlife in action, as animals emerge from winter and migratory birds return. From paddling alongside wild ponies on Virginia‚Äôs Eastern Shore to spotting baby bison in Yellowstone National Park, here are seven unforgettable adventures that will take you to wildlife-rich spots across the U.S. Keep in mind, however, that the best wildlife encounters happen when you keep a respectful distance and observe responsible practices, so grab your binoculars and get ready for a spring wil‚Ä¶

entry.title: Omega-3s are great for your health‚Äîbut supplements may not be
entry.summary:
Science has proven time and again that omega-3 fatty acids, or omega-3s, can be among the most important parts of a well-balanced diet. The studies show that the healthy fats can help¬†lower blood pressure,¬†improve immunity,¬†reduce joint inflammation,¬†support mental health, and even¬†diminish risks of cardiovascular disease and stroke.¬†
But most people aren't getting enough. In fact,¬†research shows¬†that some 95 percent of kids aren't meeting the recommended levels of omega-3s in their diet‚Äîand about 68 percent of adults aren't either.
(How omega-3 fatty acids help reduce inflammation.)
To increase intake, one in five people over age 60 is taking a fish oil supplement regularly and countless younger adults are doing so as well‚Äîcausing the worldwide omega-3s supplement market to‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why ancient pilgrimages are back in vogue in the UK
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the sun begins to set, the choristers file down St John‚Äôs Walk, just as they have for the past 500 years. Their cassocks swish softly, their feet tap the worn flagstones and their murmured voices rise towards rafters adorned with angels and griffins. From my room in the medieval cloisters, I follow them along the ancient passage into the cathedral and take a seat in the stalls. The aged wood creaks beneath me, prayer books shuffle quietly in hand and then, evensong begins.
Hereford Cathedral has been a site of pilgrimage since 1320, when Thomas Cantilupe, a former Bishop of Hereford, was canonised. Pilgrimages fell out of favour after the Reformation, and for centuries, no travellers have spent the night here or‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 of Europe's best beginner hikes
entry.summary:
Tre Cime di Lavaredo in the Italian Dolomites offers extraordinary scenery at minimum effort. Whether you‚Äôre longing for the Austrian Alps, Italian coasts or historic French hilltop towns, these eight easy beginner trails range from short but memorable walks to multi-day adventures through Europe‚Äôs most impressive landscapes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Tempted by the idea of hiking holidays but worry they‚Äôll be too gruelling? Here are eight beginner-friendly hikes that are less about endurance and more about the simple pleasures of the Great Outdoors. Some will take you just a few hours, others last several days. But regardless of which you choose to tackle, each has been chosen for their combination of easy terrain, well-maintained path‚Ä¶

entry.title: UNICEF condemns looting of lifesaving supplies for children in Sudan
entry.summary: The UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) on Friday strongly condemned the looting of vital humanitarian supplies from Al Bashair Hospital in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, warning that the theft puts thousands of malnourished children and mothers at risk.

entry.title: ‚ÄòThe poison of racism continues to infect our world‚Äô, Guterres warns on International Day
entry.summary: The United Nations commemorated the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination on Friday, calling on the global community to uphold its shared responsibility to combat racism in all its forms.

entry.title: Middle East crisis spirals amid mounting civilian deaths, aid blockade
entry.summary: The Israel-Palestine conflict is descending further into violence, with mounting civilian casualties in the West Bank and a deepening humanitarian crisis in Gaza, the UN‚Äôs top envoy for the region warned on Friday.

entry.title: Children, refugees pay hefty price of global aid funding crisis
entry.summary: Children, refugees and displaced people worldwide are paying the price for the deep-seated funding crisis that has engulfed the international aid sector, made worse by pronounced cuts in Washington, the UN children‚Äôs and refugee agencies said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Running to bomb shelters, nothing new for Ukraine‚Äôs schoolchildren
entry.summary: Classes cut short by air raid sirens have become a routine part of school life for many Ukrainian youngsters in the three years since Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion began,¬†a new UN report published on Friday details.

entry.title: Exhausted Gazans wake from another night of Israeli bombing: UN aid teams
entry.summary: Israel‚Äôs renewed bombing campaign and intensifying ground operation in Gaza are reversing gains achieved during the brief ceasefire, UN humanitarians inside the devastated enclave said on Friday.

entry.title: Telltale Data Signs of Bogus Scientific Papers and Fraudulent Academic Research
entry.summary: Two scientists and an editor spent six months investigating so-called paper mills, which churn out bogus scientific papers that impede actual research on lifesaving breakthroughs.

author.name: Frederik Joelving, Cyril Labb√©, and Guillaume Cabanac, The Conversation
