entry.title: This Japanese culinary curiosity promises 7 extra years of life
entry.summary:
Despite its dark exterior, the inside of the black egg is surprisingly white. Commercial production of black eggs boiled in the bubbling hot springs of Owakudani began several decades ago‚Äîbut the longevity myth tied to them stretches back much further.
The first thing that hits you isn‚Äôt the sight of the steam rising in ghostly tendrils from the mountainside, nor the warning signs advising visitors of the area‚Äôs volcanic activity. It‚Äôs the scent. A thick, mineral-rich fog clings to the air, an unmistakable reminder that the earth here is very much alive.
Welcome to Owakudani, one of the most otherworldly destinations in Japan. Here the ground exhales plumes of sulfur, the rocky terrain is tinged in shades of ochre and gray, and the region‚Äôs most famous culinary delicacy ‚Äî bla‚Ä¶

entry.title: How do you save a language from extinction?
entry.summary:
Ingrid Gaup braids dried "shoe grass" to insulate winter boots, a technique S√°mi people have used for generations. Like the efforts to save the Inari S√°mi language, practices like this help keep Indigenous knowledge alive. In the 1990s, fewer than 350 people spoke Inari S√°mi. Today, experts say about 500 people speak the near-extinct language, and the movement to learn it is growing.
In 1996, linguist Marja-Liisa Olthuis had a difficult decision to make. Should she speak to her newborn daughter in Finnish or Inari S√°mi, the endangered language of her Indigenous community?
With only a few hundred speakers left, Inari S√°mi was rarely heard outside a handful of families. Finnish, spoken by millions, would have been the easier choice‚Äîespecially since Olthuis had moved away from La‚Ä¶

entry.title: It's not too early to make plans for America's 250th birthday in 2026
entry.summary:
Cities and towns all over the United States are getting ready to celebrate the country's big 250th birthday in 2026, and they're doing it early. All over the country, cities and towns are going all out for next year‚Äôs semiquincentennial party. Here are our 9 picks for where to go‚Äîand how to start celebrating now.
Many states and cities have bragging rights to being the ‚Äúfirst‚Äù and ‚Äúoldest‚Äù in the nation for different milestones throughout America's history. And with the big blowout birthday coming up in 2026, they‚Äôre getting ready to show off, including at historic inns where George Washington really¬†did¬†spend the night.
In some places, festivities have already been planned. But stay tuned, there‚Äôs a lot more red, white, and blue to be announced; check America250 and the state‚Ä¶

entry.title: How cherry blossoms came to the United States
entry.summary: People enjoy an afternoon with cherry blossom trees in bloom at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on April 24, 2024, in New York City. The cherry blossoms, one of the garden's spring highlights, have reached peak bloom, which will last for a limited time before the ground turns pink with petals. The Japanese sakura trees made their way to America's capital with help from a few unlikely adventurers and advocates. Springtime in Washington, D.C. kicks off every year with the city's famous Cherry Blossom Festival, when the fluffy pink cherry trees around the National Mall and Tidal Basin burst into bloom. Hundreds of thousands flock there to take in the beautiful flowers, making it one of Washington's most well-loved events. It's hard to imagine, but more th‚Ä¶

entry.title: How do seals know how long to hold their breath?
entry.summary: A new study suggests gray seals (Halichoerus grypus) can sense the level of oxygen in their blood and that the animals change their diving behavior in response.  The sea mammals may actually be able to sense the amount of oxygen in their blood‚Äîsomething we humans can't do. Seals can do many things humans can‚Äôt, of course, but a clever experiment in Scotland has just uncovered a new ability. A study published in Science this week suggests that the marine mammals can sense the amount of oxygen in their blood, and change their diving behavior in response. All animals extract oxygen from the air they breathe in, and release carbon dioxide (CO2) from their blood in the air they exhale. Most mammals can‚Äôt directly detect oxygen levels in the blood supplying their tissues‚Ä¶

entry.title: When You Will Die

entry.title: Debunking the myths behind Harry Houdini's life‚Äîand death
entry.summary:
His name is now synonymous with breaking out of impossible situations and surviving death-defying stunts, including one that came with the warning ‚ÄúFailure Means a Drowning Death.‚Äù To his audiences, Harry Houdini‚Äôs skills seemed almost supernatural. But to Houdini himself, an immigrant who embraced showmanship to escape grinding poverty, his abilities were built entirely on intelligence, reason, and meticulous preparation.
Always looking over his shoulder at imitators, Houdini spent his career upping his game‚Äìand the stakes. In 1903, in Russia, he requested to be locked naked in a freezing prison van the tsarist police used to transport prisoners on a three-week trip to Siberia. To the astonishment of the guards, Houdini broke out after 45 minutes. From then on, his acts became riskie‚Ä¶

entry.title: 25 new ways to see the U.S. in 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Point to any part of America‚Äôs vast 50-state map and there‚Äôs an adventure to be had. Always experimenting, forever innovating ‚Äî there‚Äôs never a dull moment in the US and this year brings a host of new tours, anniversaries, relaunched trains and overlooked regions to explore. From the surf-lashed West Coast to the vast forests of New York State ‚Äî and all the canyons, vineyards and honky-tonks in between ‚Äî travellers are guaranteed to find their perfect slice of Americana in this list of experiences for the year ahead.
Amtrak‚Äôs Southern Gulf coast train is set to become one of the USA‚Äôs great rail routes when it reopens in spring 2025, following a 20-year hiatus thanks to the damage wrought by Hurricane Katrina. Th‚Ä¶

entry.title: End of eternal ice: Many glaciers will not survive this century, climate scientists say
entry.summary: Glaciers in many regions will not survive the 21st century if they keep melting at the current rate, potentially jeopardising hundreds of millions of people living downstream, UN climate experts said on the first¬†World Day for Glaciers.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Free societies are good for business says UN rights chief, wrapping up visit to Kyrgyzstan
entry.summary: Respect for human rights is not only a moral obligation but a necessity for economic stability, the UN‚Äôs top human rights official said on Thursday, during a visit to the Central Asian country of Kyrgyzstan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria's humanitarian crisis: 16.5 million in need amid continuing conflict
entry.summary: The legacy of the Syrian conflict, which saw the overthrow of the Assad regime in December last year, is that 16.5 million people are in dire need of assistance, making it one of the largest humanitarian crises globally, a senior UN humanitarian said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Trailblazers: UN‚Äôs ‚Äòfounding mothers‚Äô remind all people to stand up for human rights
entry.summary: Silence is not an option in the fight for human rights ‚Äì that was the message on Thursday at an event honouring the legacy of the women who have shaped the United Nations‚Äô commitment to gender equality.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO give clean bill of health to cities taking action on preventable diseases
entry.summary: Three cities that share a healthy vision for their residents won UN World Health Organization awards on Thursday for their smoke-free parks, clean air initiatives and obesity-busting school lunch initiatives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: ‚ÄòBring them all home now‚Äô, freed hostage tells Security Council
entry.summary: A senior UN political affairs official called for Israel and Hamas to restore the shattered ceasefire in Gaza on Thursday and release all remaining hostages, while one of those freed told the Security Council of his 500-day ordeal in captivity.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Civilians targeted as hostilities intensify in the capital
entry.summary: Dozens of civilians, including local humanitarian volunteers, have been killed by artillery shelling and aerial bombardment in the eastern part of Sudan‚Äôs capital, Khartoum, the UN Human Rights Office (OHCHR) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres welcomes deals to halt energy attacks in Ukraine, Russia

entry.title: The reason dementia rates are rising is surprisingly simple
entry.summary:
In January, a study published in the journal Nature Medicine suggested that by 2060, the number of Americans with dementia will double to a total of one million. Also doubling: The estimated lifetime risk of developing the condition, compared to previous estimates.
Figures like these can sound scary ‚Äî and indeed, dementia projections carry some warnings. For one, they suggest the U.S. urgently needs to pour resources into growing its caregiving workforce to meet future needs. But paradoxically, this number also tells a success story.
Today, thanks to decades of social and medical progress, more Americans than ever are living long enough to get dementia; in the past, more people would have died of cardiovascular disease or cancer at earlier ages. These health advances have also de‚Ä¶

entry.title: The best view of the northern lights involves a lot of travel‚Äîbut it is so worth it
entry.summary:
Peak northern lights viewing in northern Norwary typically happens between November and February. The aurora borealis has jumped to the top of many travelers' wish lists, creating a tourism boom in the northernmost reaches of our planet. This writer found a unique experience in northern Norway.
There are somewhere around one septillion stars in the universe. On a clear night in the middle of a quiet birch forest in northern Norway, it feels as if you can see every single one of them. Tiny dots of starlight on a spectrum of brightness dotted every corner of the night sky in a celestial show that, for me, has only been rivaled by what I‚Äôve seen in the middle of the American desert, far removed from any source of light.
However, I wasn‚Äôt in northern Norway just to stargaze (thoug‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2024 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on face-to-face interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Verian. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Here are more details about our international survey methodology and country-specific sample designs. The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Marriage, childbirth and retirement statistics
entry.summary: To help place the ideal ages provided by respondents in context, we compiled data on when in life people around the world actually get married, have their first child and become eligible for certain retirement benefits. Average age at first marriage comes from the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA), Population Division. [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix A: Marriage, childbirth and retirement statistics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. What is the best age to buy a home?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to buy a first home is just before 30. The post 3. What is the best age to buy a home? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. What is the best age to retire?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to retire is around 58 years old. The age adults can start receiving retirement benefits varies by country. The post 4. What is the best age to retire? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. What is the best age to have a first child?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to have a child is around 26 years old. Women in the countries polled generally give birth a bit later in life. The post 2. What is the best age to have a first child? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. What is the best age to get married?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to get married is around 26 years old. In general, people in the countries polled do marry in their 20s. The post 1. What is the best age to get married? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What Age Do People Around the World Think Is Best to Reach Major Life Milestones?
entry.summary: People in mostly middle-income survey countries say it‚Äôs ideal to start a family and own a home by 30, and retire by 60. The post What Age Do People Around the World Think Is Best to Reach Major Life Milestones? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Overlanding in Alaska, where glaciers meet bear country
entry.summary:
Alaska offers an abundance of different terrains to explore. Travelling in Alaska ‚Äî the US‚Äôs final frontier ‚Äî can feel like jumping through a wormhole. Time here is marked not by the clock, but by the changing of the seasons. Though cruising is a popular way to explore, travelling by land allows more exposure to the wild landscapes of south-central Alaska, from the glaciers of Prince William Sound to a park where travellers can walk with bears.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). After hiking in Chugach State Park, just east of Anchorage, where trails weave between hemlock and spruce trees, it‚Äôs onwards to Lake Clark National Park. Reached via a small ‚Äòtundra tyre‚Äô plane, it‚Äôs a rare place where travellers can get relatively close to grizzlies in the wild, accompanied by bear biologists. This is possible thanks to the neutral relationship the park‚Äôs lodges have nurtured with the coastal brown bears. You might find them among pink fireweed plants, which bloom white before wilting to brown by winter. At 27 miles long, the Matanuska Glacier is the largest in the US accessible by road. It takes less than two hours to get here from Anchorage along the scenic Glenn Highway, and many who visit Alaska by land make a detour to this rippling sea of ice on the way from Anchorage to Denali National Park. Travellers passing through the Matanuska Valley can drive right up to the base of the glacier and walk on it with a guide or try ice climbing. Tours provide equipment such as helmets and crampons, and give a unique, up-close perspective on the glacier‚Äôs eerie fissures, luminous blue caves and walls of ice that groan and creak. Published in the USA guide, available with the Jan/Feb 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe to¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: How Thailand became a world leader in edible insects
entry.summary:
Jars of edible insects are arranged to showcase their diversity in the kitchen of Akkee, a Michelin-starred restaurant in the outskirts of Bangkok that utilizes a variety of seasonal insects in their dishes. Gourmet dishes, cricket burgers, buttery bamboo caterpillars‚ÄîThai edible insect business is booming. Can it inspire the world?
Growing up in Thailand‚Äôs northeastern Isan region, Suwimon Chantajohn learned from her grandfather which insects were best to eat. Captivated by his stories of surviving on bugs during his military service in World War II, she spent her childhood scouring the dry fields for crickets, bamboo worms, and scarab beetles hiding in the grass, under bark, or beneath cow dung.
As an adult, she wanted to start her own business and traveled the world. While‚Ä¶

entry.title: Celebrate 850 years of Glasgow‚Äîhere's what to see and do
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Glasgow is famously friendly ‚Äî and famously rainy, with some 170 drizzly days each year. But the grey weather comes with an upside: this city pours its heart and soul into its cultural pursuits. After all, when there‚Äôs little chance of lolling around in the sun, you may as well start an art movement, a band or a restaurant.
The household names to have come out of Glasgow are legion ‚Äî from designer-architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh, football manager Alex Ferguson and singer Lulu to actor Peter Capaldi and comedian Frankie Boyle ‚Äî and you‚Äôll find some of the UK‚Äôs best theatres, music venues and museums here.
Walking around the city centre, Glasgow‚Äôs prosperous past is evident: its grand Victorian banking halls‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: ‚ÄòDramatic escalation‚Äô as bombardments intensify and displacement surges
entry.summary: Israeli bombardments continued across Gaza on Wednesday, killing hundreds more people ‚Äì many of them women and children ‚Äì and leaving widespread destruction in its wake, according to local authorities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukrainians tortured, raped, executed by Russian captors, Human Rights Council hears
entry.summary: The Human Rights Council on Wednesday heard gruesome testimony of torture, rape and execution of Ukrainian detainees and soldiers allegedly committed by Russian forces, as a high-level independent probe into Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion delivered its latest mandated report in Geneva.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Violence triggers record displacements in Haiti‚Äôs capital
entry.summary: In just one month, intensifying violence has forced over 60,000 people to flee their homes in Haiti‚Äôs capital, Port-au-Prince, marking another grim record in the country‚Äôs worsening humanitarian crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN staff member killed in central Gaza blast, five others injured
entry.summary: At least one UN staffer has been killed and at least five others injured ‚Äì several very severely ‚Äì following an explosion at their official premises in Deir al Balah in the central Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haitian media struggle to survive in face of attacks, revenue collapse
entry.summary: An increase in attacks on media outlets in Haiti by armed gangs which control most of the capital Port-au-Prince is intended to intimidate journalists and instill chaos according to the UN agency for culture, UNESCO.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Animal sounds in different languages
entry.summary: The purpose of onomatopoeia is to imitate sounds with words, so you might‚Ä¶ Tags: animals, Pudding, sound, Vivian Li

entry.title: By the time I reach him
entry.summary: ‚ÄòMy dad will be gone by the time I reach him‚Äô ‚Äì a filmmaker captures the first time their father forgets who they are - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: Fighting a War with Data Journalism: Ukraine‚Äôs Texty and the Battle for Truth
entry.summary: The team at the award-winning data journalism outlet suspected that Russia would invade ‚Äî they could see clues in the data. We profile the team and their work combating false conflict narratives.

entry.title: What toll does spaceflight take on astronauts?
entry.summary:
On September 15, 2021, a SpaceX Dragon capsule carried the Inspiration4 crew into space via a Falcon 9 rocket. During their three-day mission, spacecraft reached an altitude of 575 kilometers (km) above Earth‚Äôs surface, farther in space than the orbit of the International Space Station, which ranges from 370km to 460km. A new database aims to pave the way for a better understanding of space health and medicine as more civilian missions launch.
Over the past five decades, under 700 humans have flown in space. Nearly every one of those humans were professionally trained astronauts and in similar peak physical condition. And most of those astronauts were men. But in 2021, the first space mission with four civilian astronauts‚Äîmeaning, not government agency astronauts‚Äîflew. It opened a ‚Ä¶

entry.title: This may be Europe‚Äôs best-kept secret for family vacations
entry.summary:
With calm waves and sandy shores, it's easy to spend a day on the beach in the Algarve. With its pristine beaches, charming fishing villages, vineyards, and medieval castles, the Algarve region of Portugal offers a wide range of adventures.
  When you hear someone say they are planning a family trip to Portugal, Lisbon is often the destination that comes to mind. And while Portugal's capital is worth the hype, you'd miss out on Europe's best-kept secret for family vacations, the Algarve. Located less than three hours south of Lisbon, the Algarve (from Arabic‚Äôs al-garbh for "the west‚Äù) is the southernmost region of Portugal. Renowned for its golden cliffs, silky sand beaches, picturesque towns, and delectable cuisine, it provides the perfect blend of adventure, relaxati‚Ä¶

entry.title: These fish can spot their favorite divers
entry.summary:
Several times during almost 20 years of conducting research on fish in the wild, Alex Jordan, a researcher who leads the Behavioural Evolution Lab at the Max Planck Institute of Animal Behavior, had the feeling that the fish he was studying were learning to recognize and follow him or his colleagues.
‚ÄúThere were a lot of times when it was obvious¬†to us that fish were recognizing us,‚Äù he recalls.
But while scientists seemed to intuitively suspect this, no studies looked at this phenomenon in the wild.
‚Äú[Fish] are a lot more complicated than we give them credit for,‚Äù says Cait Newport, a marine biologist at Oxford University who wasn‚Äôt involved in the new research.
To test their hunch, Jordan and his colleagues traveled to the French Mediterranean island of Corsica, where‚Ä¶

entry.title: Astronauts getting stuck in space is more common than you think
entry.summary:
NASA astronauts (clockwise from bottom) Matthew Dominick, Jeanette Epps, Sunita Williams, Mike Barratt, Tracy Dyson, and Barry Wilmore, pose for a team portrait on the International Space Station on July 11. Williams and Wilmore were supposed to spend roughly eight days in space, after arriving on the Boeing Starliner's first flight in June. As Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore finally return home, here's where they fit in a long list of astronauts who got to spend more time on the ISS than expected.
Thanks to technical problems with their Boeing Starliner spacecraft, Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore have spent a lot more time on the International Space Station than originally planned. After around nine months in space, they are returning to Earth aboard a SpaceX capsule with two ‚Ä¶

entry.summary: The classic movie The Sound of Music celebrates its 60th anniversary in 2025, but beyond its milestone celebrations this year, there are several experiences inspired by the famous flick that fans should not miss out on when visiting Salzburg, Austria. From the hills of the opening scene to the mountain over which they escape, here‚Äôs how to follow in the footsteps of the von Trapp family in real life. entry.title: Explore 7 of the best pilgrimages in the UK
entry.summary:
The Mourne mountains offer a fantastic pitstop on the St Patrick's Way in Northern Ireland. While traditional religious practices may be on the decline, pilgrimages ‚Äî meditative, multi-day hikes ‚Äî are experiencing a resurgence. Explore the routes that are offering new, mindful journeys in our increasingly secular world.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Back in the day, a pilgrimage meant a journey to a sacred place as an act of religious devotion. Today, for increasing numbers of pilgrims, it‚Äôs a journey made with purpose and a touch of spirituality ‚Äî though not necessarily driven by faith. The UK has become one of the world‚Äôs most secular countries; the last census saw the percentage of Christians in England and Wales drop from 59% to 46%. An‚Ä¶

entry.title: Snowboarder Jeremy Jones fights to keep our winters cold
entry.summary:
Jeremy Jones photographed by Jonas Fredwall Karlsson in Olympic Valley, California Along with his outdoor-sports peers, the backcountry legend is leading an unlikely contingent of climate activists on a mission to keep winter powder fresh and abundant.
A pioneer of big-mountain snowboarding, Jeremy Jones watched as helicopters made remote backcountry runs suddenly reachable, enabling access to lines that had once been unfathomably remote. ‚ÄúWe would get dropped in the mountains and link up these runs where you hike and ride and hike and ride,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI was like, Oh my God, this is where I need to be.‚Äù But he had misgivings about the means of ascent. ‚ÄúI knew, when I got in a helicopter, I was taking up resources,‚Äù he says. He began hiking up mountains instead and found the experie‚Ä¶

entry.title: Mountaineer Carla P√©rez wants to empower everyone
entry.summary:
Carla P√©rez photographed by Nanna Heitmann in Kyanjin Gompa, Nepal Climbing, she says, allows for an ‚Äúexploration of your body, of your limits, of the possibilities that you have.‚Äù She‚Äôs working to ensure people with disabilities have the chance to experience it.
Carla P√©rez can feel the difference when she crosses the invisible line that marks 8,300 meters, or roughly 27,000 feet, above sea level. ‚ÄúBefore that wall, you still have a lot of control over what you think and what you do,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs, like, normal‚Äîalmost normal.‚Äù‚ÄØBut when P√©rez, 42, climbs higher, things change. ‚ÄúYou start to lose your control of your mind. You cannot talk very well‚Äîit‚Äôs like you are drunk,‚Äù she explains. Her body responds sluggishly to her commands: Thoughts and movements materialize on an agoniz‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Shu Yang finds inspiration for game-changing new ideas
entry.summary:
For Shu Yang, ideas are everywhere. Sometimes nature provokes inspiration. Other times, a problem causes Yang to see a solution that already exists in the natural world. While trying to create a ‚Äúbuilding envelope‚Äù that could reflect sunlight and collect water to passively heat and cool buildings, she looked to tornado vortices for a new structure for perforated window covers. The dry, grooved skin of the African elephant helped her envision a new kind of stucco that would keep temperatures down in regions experiencing life-threatening heat waves. Yang also developed an adhesive that‚Äôs strong enough to hold shelving on walls yet porous enough to be removed if the glue is remoistened. Snail secretion gave her a model to perfect the design.¬†
Yang, a chemical and biomolecular engineer at‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pattie Gonia wants to make the outdoors more welcoming
entry.summary:
Pattie Gonia photographed by Djeneba Aduayom near Three Fingered Jack peak in Oregon The nature-loving drag queen and environmentalist has big plans for making LGBTQ people feel more comfortable in the outdoors community.
The outdoors can sometimes feel hostile for the queer community. That‚Äôs a conclusion Wyn Wiley reached as a kid at a summer camp run by the Boy Scouts. ‚ÄúI was indoctrinated into this militaristic, masculine outdoor system of ‚ÄòYou have to be strong to survive,‚Äô‚Äù Wiley recalls.
Today that kid raised under a stifling vision of the outdoors leads a movement built on a very different story‚Äîand does so in heels. After going viral in 2018 for hiking in six-inch-heeled boots, the world‚Äôs premier ‚Äúbackpacking queen‚Äù was born: Pattie Gonia, an activist in drag who‚Äôs t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Arlo Parks is ready to amplify other peoples' stories
entry.summary:
Arlo Parks photographed by Micaiah Carter in Los Angeles In her songs, the London-born musician probes her intimate moments of her life. In her work as UNICEF‚Äôs youngest U.K. ambassador, she‚Äôs trying to amplify other people‚Äôs stories.
The London-born musician and poet Arlo Parks makes indie pop with the warmth and tenderness of folk. And since her 2021 debut album, Collapsed in Sunbeams, she‚Äôs become known for songs that are so strikingly candid and familiar that they can seem like diorama boxes filled with life‚Äôs tiniest moments. ‚ÄúI just have my notebook for every record,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúand I‚Äôm collecting fragments and phrases and nuggets from my life, and that‚Äôs where the music comes from.‚Äù¬†
Because her music is so possessed by interior life, it can naturally seem to yearn for ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Tayshan Hayden-Smith helps rebuild places‚Äîwith plants
entry.summary:
Tayshan Hayden-Smith photographed by Robin Hammond in the North Kensington neighborhood of London The former pro soccer player has returned home to London with a plan to rejuvenate the city‚Äôs neighborhoods‚Äîand empower its young people‚Äîwith urban gardening.
When Tayshan Hayden-Smith was growing up with his three siblings in London public housing, he dreamed of playing for Arsenal, the famous football club, and the family‚Äôs small garden became his pitch. He honed his skills dribbling between his mother‚Äôs rosebushes and lavender plants, his shots careening off her avocado tree. ‚ÄúIt was like the garden versus football,‚Äù he recalls. For a time, in the backyard and in his heart, football reigned supreme, and by the time he was 20, he was playing professionally in Austria.‚ÄØ¬†
Then, on‚Ä¶

entry.title: Meet the builders making schools from plastic waste
entry.summary:
Isabel Cristina G√°mez and Oscar Andr√©s M√©ndez photographed by Robin Hammond in Bogot√°, Colombia Isabel Cristina G√°mez and Oscar Andr√©s M√©ndez have developed a novel system that repurposes shampoo bottles and food packaging into a modular system far cheaper than traditional construction.
The idea was simple yet profound. What if you could use the plastic waste littering your home country to help solve its housing crisis? For architect Oscar Andr√©s M√©ndez and his business partner, electronics engineer Isabel Cristina G√°mez, that inspiration led to an invention that embodies their core values.¬†¬†
Their Colombia-based company, Conceptos Pl√°sticos, transforms plastic, including bags, snack-food containers, and shampoo bottles, into a modular building system of bricks and columns.‚ÄØTh‚Ä¶

entry.title: Maya Gabeira surfs big waves‚Äîand helps to rid them of plastic
entry.summary:
Maya Gabeira photographed by Matthieu Paley in Nazar√©, Portugal As a big-wave surfer, the Brazilian adrenaline junkie set records at the highest surf break on Earth. She‚Äôs still committed to the ocean‚Äînow, though, she‚Äôs dedicating herself to helping keep it clean for future generations.
For much of the year, the ocean at NazareÃÅ, a fishing village on Portugal‚Äôs coast, is placid. But in the winter, certain storms funnel swells through an underwater canyon, transforming the waves into moving mountains of water so colossal they have been described as the Everest of the ocean.
Big-wave surfers have made pilgrimages to the town since 2011, when a video of Garrett McNamara barreling down a 78-foot wave established it as having one of the planet‚Äôs biggest breaks. Over much of the pas‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gabriela Hearst is pushing the edge in sustainable fashion
entry.summary:
Gabriela Hearst photographed by Joyce Ng in Hearst‚Äôs atelier in New York City Long before it became trendy in fashion circles, environmentalism was the guiding ethos in the designer‚Äôs work. ‚ÄúWhat am I going to do, another collection based on a ‚Äô70s icon?‚Äù
A visitor to the Manhattan office of Gabriela Hearst doesn‚Äôt need to peruse the impeccably well-made clothes to spot proof of the fashion designer‚Äôs impact. ‚ÄúThose recycled cardboard hangers you see?‚Äù Hearst says, pointing. ‚ÄúWe were one of the first to develop them.‚Äù Her abhorrence of the plastic kind owes to its frequent fate: the landfill.¬†
Today the 48-year-old designer‚Äîwho grew up on a ranch in Uruguay and launched her eponymous brand a decade ago‚Äîis a prestige player in the world of fashion and embodies the quiet luxury ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lucie Basch wants to stop uneaten food from going to waste
entry.summary:
Lucie Basch photographed by Robin Hammond in Paris At 24, she rallied restaurants to join her app and pledge to distribute uneaten food. The app didn‚Äôt exist yet. Now Too Good to Go has more than 100 million users.
When she was 24 years old, Lucie Basch left a promising career at Nestl√© determined to build an app to fight food waste. She had zero coding knowledge, no marketing experience, and no funding. What she did have, however, was a simmering disdain for just how much good food winds up in the trash‚Äîabout 30 percent of global production‚Äîwhich creates as much as 10 percent of greenhouse gas emissions as it rots.¬†
Food waste happens all along the supply chain, but another thing Basch did not have was specialized expertise in agriculture or manufacturing. So she focused on w‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Yara Shahidi is speaking up for optimism
entry.summary: Yara Shahidi photographed by Micaiah Carter in Malibu, California The voice-of-a-generation star of Black-ish and Grown-ish is searching for bright spots in tricky times. ‚ÄúYoung people rise to the occasion time and time again.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhat does optimism mean to you right now?‚Äù It‚Äôs a question that Yara Shahidi, best known for her role as the Gen Z cool girl Zoey Johnson on the hit show Black-ish and its spin-off, Grown-ish (both produced by ABC, which shares a parent company with National Geographic), often asks at the beginning of her new podcast, The Optimist Project, which wrestles with how to live a more fulfilling life.‚ÄØ¬† As suicide rates rise in the United States and the world seems awash in anxiety-inducing headlines, it‚Äôs a question that has become ever m‚Ä¶

entry.title: Bj√∂rk the artist is unconstrained. The activist is pragmatic.
entry.summary:
Bj√∂rk always seems to inhabit an alternate universe‚Äîa dreamlike space of the highest creative ambition, free from the constraints that govern mere mortals. Which makes it all the more jarring when she injects her work with a dose of cold reality. In January she released a concert film shot during her recent Cornucopia tour. The show featured signature Bj√∂rk flourishes, including expansive arrangements of Iceland‚Äôs Hamrahl√≠√∞ Choir; giant, psychedelic projections of fungi; and the flashing of an environmental manifesto making an explicit appeal to the most urgent issue of our time: ‚ÄúThe Paris climate accord is a modern utopia impossible to imagine, but overcoming our environmental challenges is the only way we can survive.‚Äù¬†
Over Zoom one day last winter, she explained what she was gett‚Ä¶

entry.title: The doctor who believes pig hearts could end our organ shortage
entry.summary:
Muhammad Mansoor Mohiuddin photographed by Jonas Fredwall Karlsson at the University of Maryland School of Medicine in Baltimore Surgeon Muhammad Mansoor Mohiuddin is a leader in the novel field of xenotransplantation‚Äîtransferring organs from one species to another‚Äîin his case, from pigs to humans.
Sometimes tragedies can be breakthroughs. Or the beginnings of breakthroughs. That‚Äôs what happened a few years ago when a University of Maryland Medical Center surgical team, led by Muhammad Mansoor Mohiuddin and Bartley Griffith, performed a revolutionary new procedure on a 57-year-old who had terminal heart failure. David Bennett, Sr., had been denied a traditional heart transplant due to a variety of health factors. Thousands of people each year face a similar reality, in part because‚Ä¶

entry.title: Adam McKay believes we need humor to stave off disaster
entry.summary: Adam McKay photographed by Sebastian Kim, August Image The Anchorman and Don‚Äôt Look Up filmmaker thinks the best way to encourage climate awareness isn‚Äôt with sober fact‚Äîit‚Äôs with biting satire.  A few years back, when filmmaker Adam McKay released his movie Don‚Äôt¬†Look Up‚Äîan apocalyptic satire that uses a killer comet as a metaphor for climate change‚Äîhe was searching for a new way to talk about disaster. ‚ÄúAs horrific as this all is,‚Äù McKay says about climate change, ‚Äúit‚Äôs important that we create a culture around dealing with this epic, literally geological catastrophe we‚Äôre confronting with humor.‚Äù‚ÄØ‚ÄØ¬† When he started promoting the film, he got to wondering: Could humor actually galvanize some kind of response to the climate crisis? entry.title: How Planespotter and Other Transportation Enthusiast Sites Can Unlock Investigations
entry.summary: At NICAR25, data reporters detailed how amateur transportation enthusiasts are a valuable, media-friendly, and underused source of critical tips and information for investigations.

entry.title: Here‚Äôs why white sneakers are actually pretty great travel shoes
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Shoes are the biggest puzzle when it comes to packing. What‚Äôs versatile, won‚Äôt take up too much space or bring your luggage over the weight limit? If you‚Äôre not checking in a bag, choosing wisely is even more essential. The answer: A white sneaker.
That may sound surprising, but we love packing white sneakers for trips, as long as they‚Äôre properly prepped and maintained. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great staple,‚Äù says New-York based freelance fashion director Sam Chad‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to travel like a local in Japan
entry.summary:
Travel experts recommend a relaxing, stress-free stay at a traditional Japanese inn or ryokan when visiting Japan. It‚Äôs a not-to-be-missed experience and a local favorite.  From subtropical islands to chilled-out ski resorts, there are so many places in Japan that don't suffer from the overtourism that's challenging more popular areas.
Japan is a deservedly popular destination, but travelers often wind up seeing the same sights and miss out on the far-flung, quieter, or less obvious corners of the country. To see a softer side of Japan, we asked locals, from writers to motorcycle enthusiasts, nonprofit workers to photographers, to share something about the places they love best.¬† Travelers with only a day to spare should consider visiting Mount Takao‚Äîthe most prominent‚Ä¶

The 31 best Greek islands to visit in 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From the gastronomic isles of the Cyclades to the enigmatic ruins of the Dodecanese, each of the six main Greek island groups has its own distinct character. Yet, look closely and you‚Äôll find that more unites than sets them apart: there are secluded towns loved by local gourmands, hidden coves brimming with mythical associations and, above all, a natural splendour that‚Äôs captured the minds of artists and adventurers through the ages. Here are the best Greek islands to visit.
According to Greek mythology, it was Poseidon who seized a chunk of Kos and hurled it on top of a fiery Titan called Polyvotis ‚Äî creating the volcanic island of Nisyros, with its enormous, sulphurous caldera. The volcano is active, but trave‚Ä¶

entry.title: How waves of immigration have created culinary magic in Tampa
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As I wander past the New Orleans-style iron verandahs, cigar shops and organic ice cream parlours on Tampa‚Äôs palm-tree-lined 7th Avenue, I realise I‚Äôm being followed by a rooster. Like me, he seems to be heading to The Columbia ‚Äî Florida‚Äôs oldest Spanish restaurant.
It‚Äôs a balmy November afternoon, and elderly gents and young people are shooting the breeze while smoking cigars in armchairs on the pavement, but nobody seems phased by my feathered friend. Here in Tampa‚Äôs Ybor City neighbourhood, the rooster is king.
An official edict states the chickens must be allowed to roam free in honour of the area‚Äôs original Cuban immigrants, who raised the birds. Along with settlers from Spain, Italy, Germany, Switzerland‚Ä¶

entry.title: Top 10 things to do in Japan
entry.summary:
Travelers should visit Senso-ji temple, Tokyo‚Äôs oldest-established temple located in the city‚Äôs Asakusa neighborhood. It's just one of 10 things first-time visitors should do when exploring Japan. In a nation as culturally rich as Japan, it can be hard to know how to spend your time there. Here are ten of our favorite things to do.
Japan is an alluring destination because of its many juxtapositions. Neon skyscrapers tower over Shinto shrines, and salarymen ride the train next to Harajuku girls. The Land of the Rising Sun also has diverse climates and cultural attractions to please every style of traveler. Adventurers can ski Niseko‚Äôs slopes or hike Mount Fuji, while food lovers can eat their fill of street snacks in Osaka. Those seeking a more ‚ÄúZen‚Äù vacation can relax in outdoor h‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the equinox ushers in the arrival of spring
entry.summary:
Every six months, once in March and again in September, an equinox splits Earth‚Äôs day almost in half, giving us about 12 hours of daylight and 12 of night.
On March 20, 2025, the vernal equinox will signal the coming of spring for the Northern Hemisphere. Then, in September, nature will once again bring us the autumnal¬†equinox, the time of year that ushers in fall in the North. Those dates are swapped for the vernal and autumnal equinoxes in the Southern Hemisphere.
(Here's why each season begins twice.) undefinedWhat are equinoxes? What causes these astronomical events? Find out how they influence the seasons and hours of daylight on each planet. Our planet normally orbits the sun on an axis that‚Äôs tilted 23.5 degrees, meaning that the hemispheres trade off getting ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Joint UN meeting tackles small arms control to foster sustainable development
entry.summary: On Monday, during a meeting of the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council, UN officials and disarmament experts emphasized the urgent need to tackle the widespread issue of small arms and light weapons. They warned that the stakes are higher than ever in a world increasingly plagued by conflict and crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE NOW: Security Council meets on Gaza crisis, UN calls for urgent renewal of ceasefire and hostage releases
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to discuss the Middle East crisis exactly two months since the start of the fragile Gaza ceasefire and hostages deal came into effect. That has been shattered by deadly Israeli airstrikes overnight, following a two-week aid blockade which has strained critical supplies. Well over 400 Palestinians have been killed and hundreds more injured, according to local authorities. We'll have reaction from across the UN and agencies on the ground. UN News app users follow live here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: US strikes on Yemen, Gaza aid update, debt burden weighs on developing world
entry.summary: The UN on Monday expressed concern over the continued threat posed to shipping in the Red Sea by Houthi attacks from their bases in Yemen as well as recent airstrikes by the United States which have left over 50 reportedly dead.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Funding shortages risk undermining a ‚Äòwatershed moment‚Äô for Syria
entry.summary: Fourteen years of war have left Syria‚Äôs people in desperate need ‚Äì but international support is dwindling, UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres warned on Monday, calling for urgent investment in the country‚Äôs recovery.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: FAO warns of ‚Äòunprecedented‚Äô avian flu spread, in call for global action
entry.summary: The rapid spread of the highly infectious avian flu virus H5N1 has reached an ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù scale, wiping out hundreds of millions of birds worldwide and increasingly spilling over into mammals, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Afghanistan: Security Council renews UN mission as WHO warns of health catastrophe
entry.summary: The Security Council on Monday extended the mandate of the UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) for another year, as UN agencies reported sharp declines in resources for lifesaving aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Relative of Assad regime‚Äôs disappeared speaks of anguish in search for truth and justice
entry.summary: A relative of two Syrians tortured and murdered by the Assad regime has spoken of the anguish caused by their enforced disappearance during the country‚Äôs civil war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: The ‚ÄúDepartment of Government Efficiency‚Äù keeps a ‚ÄúWall of Receipts‚Äù to signal transparency‚Ä¶ Tags: DOGE, government, spending, Upshot

entry.title: Exposing Extremism Networks in Sub-Saharan Africa Using Open Source Tools
entry.summary: As extremism spreads across sub-Saharan Africa, journalists are turning to open source tools to track the networks and physical movement of these often violent groups.

entry.title: Tour the Indigenous southwest‚Äôs living history on a road trip
entry.summary:
Monument Valley is a popular destination for American road trips. A new road trip of the Southwest‚Äôs Indigenous heartlands offers travellers a greater understanding of the past, present and future of the country‚Äôs original inhabitants. Along the way, culturally sensitive tours with Native American guides explore ancient pueblos and impressive canyons.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Rain is pounding and the temperature is close to freezing. But the atmosphere inside the powwow tent at the Western Navajo Fair is electric. Here in Tuba City, Arizona, eagle feather headdresses and beaded buckskin skirts move to the beat of a drum. Green, yellow and blue ribbons flit through the air like parakeets. Dresses stitched with metal woosh like running w‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Philadelphia's Fishtown
entry.summary:
Located in the city‚Äôs River Wards, Fishtown beams with an array of restaurants, bars and a vibrant art scene. Originally settled by fishermen, this ex-industrial neighbourhood is now one of Philly‚Äôs best days out.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Philadelphia‚Äôs riverside neighbourhood of Fishtown has seen a resurgence over the past decade as its inventive restaurants, dive bars and quirky stores draw visitors from near and far. The former fishing village, which morphed into an industrial powerhouse on the Delaware River, remains a blend of narrow streets of tall townhouses and repurposed warehouses, and retains its sense of community and tradition amid its modern developments.
Many people come to Fishtown solely for the restaurants, and‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this America's greatest LGBTQ+ city break?
entry.summary:
From the pool to the cocktails, drag queen Trixie Mattel's motel has a thing for pink. This liberal, Californian desert town has reputation as one of America‚Äôs greatest LGBTQ+ destinations, cemented by the opening of a motel run by a drag queen. Here‚Äôs how to spend a fun-filled 48 hours in its thrall.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).

entry.title: Meet the LGBTQ+ pioneers of Provincetown and Salem
entry.summary:
It‚Äôs rare for a hotel to have hosted four US presidents. Rarer still for it to also have a queer nightclub in its basement ‚Äî where, during its weekly underwear parties, revellers check not only their coats but most of their clothing into the cloakroom on arrival. But Gifford House in Provincetown isn‚Äôt your average hotel. It‚Äôs the jewel in the crown of a town that prides itself on having one of the highest concentrations of same-sex households in the US.
Presidents including Theodore Roosevelt visited Provincetown when it was the last stop on the stagecoach line. Over the years, other arrivals have included whalers, sailors and artists, who have come to settle on a shoreline edged with windswept sand dunes and saltbox houses. entry.title: Where to see the world‚Äôs brightest bioluminescent tides
entry.summary:
The phenomenon requires warm, calm and windless waters, as well as low-lit new moon nights, to ensure particularly memorable displays. Watching phytoplankton illuminate the world's shores is an otherworldly experience. With a bit of luck and perseverance, these are the best places to catch the notoriously elusive natural phenomenon.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It only takes the gentle brush of a hand or slow glide of a boat to trigger the sparkling blue-green light of bioluminescent plankton, or phytoplankton. The dinoflagellates ‚Äî single-celled phytoplankton that produce oxygen in water ‚Äî emit a sparkling cold light when agitated as a protection mechanism.

entry.title: How this ‚ÄòMegalodon‚Äô goldfish got so huge
entry.summary: Corey Ketchum of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife service holds a giant goldfish found during a survey in Presque Isle, Pennsylvania. The service then posted a warning about releasing petstore goldfish on social media. Goldfish possess genetic traits that allow them to swell up to four pounds‚Äîthe size of a Chihuahua. Experts say that's why you shouldn't release them into the wild. Thinking about freeing your pet goldfish from their tank and letting them loose in a local pond or lake? ¬†Please don‚Äôt, begs the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in a recent social media post. In just two years, that harmless fish you know as ‚ÄúMr. Bubble Guppy‚Äù can turn into an ecosystem-wrecking leviathan. ¬†‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Mexican health spa helped shape modern wellness travel
entry.summary:
Before sunrise, I shuffled into a gazebo, clutching a weak cup of coffee and a portioned banana chunk, joining 15 other guests bundled up against the desert chill. After briefly learning about the 5-mile trail ahead of us, the other hikers suddenly bolted forward in a mad rush for the mountain. Welcome to Rancho La Puerta, where the day begins with gusto at dawn.
At this Tecate, Mexico, wellness resort, guests are encouraged, if not explicitly instructed, to join daily early-morning hikes during their week-long stay. As avid hikers (my husband Scott and I had recently completed the 10-day Tour du Mont Blanc in the Alps), we expected a leisurely pre-breakfast walk that aligned with the resort‚Äôs ethos of mindfulness and tranquility. When our fellow hikers sprinted for the hills, we were‚Ä¶

entry.title: The shaky science behind trendy ‚Äòsuper greens‚Äô powders
entry.summary:
Supplements known as "super greens" or "greens powders" claim to help reduce stress, improve digestion, and boost energy. But experts say there's little credible science to back it up. An occasional scoop of these crushed-up vegetables likely won‚Äôt do any harm. But experts say the benefits of these supplements are far from proven.
It‚Äôs hard to argue with the allure of a greens powder. Inside these pleasantly packaged tubs and pouches, you‚Äôll allegedly find an elite combination of crushed-up fruits and vegetables that‚Äôll boost your energy, keep you regular, lower stress, and transform you into a more optimized version of yourself. Just mix a daily scoop of these ‚Äúsuper‚Äù greens into your bottle of water or morning shake and glug it down.

entry.title: Why you should consider freezing your carbs before eating them
entry.summary:
Cooking, freezing, and reheating carbs like rice and potatoes creates resistant starch‚Äîaltering carbs in a way that can help control blood sugar levels. If you want to prevent blood sugar spikes and keep your energy levels steady, throwing foods like white rice or pasta into the freezer before eating them can help.
If you‚Äôve ever felt that mid-afternoon energy crash after a high-carb meal, or noticed that eating white rice or potatoes makes you hungrier faster, there‚Äôs a reason for that.
Carbs with a high glycemic index‚Äîlike white bread, potatoes, and white rice‚Äîbreak down too quickly into glucose and cause blood sugar spikes, which lead to a quick burst of energy followed by a crash. Knowing which carbs have a high glycemic index can help control your blood sugar. But freezin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Carolina the giant rat retires as a hero after saving many lives
entry.summary:
Carolina, an African giant pouched rat, recently retired from her job of detecting tuberculosis cases medical tests had missed. Last year, African giant pouched rats like Carolina prevented nearly 400,000 new cases of a deadly disease. It's possible because of their extreme sense of smell.
Until recently, Carolina worked Monday through Friday, with weekends off.¬†¬†¬†
At her retirement this past November, colleagues lined up to applaud her and celebrate over cake. In her seven-year career, she had detected more than 3,000 cases of tuberculosis that health clinics had missed and, as a result, likely spared more than 30,000 other people from infection.¬†
But she's not exactly your typical employee. Carolina is an African giant pouched rat who can screen 100 sputum (i.e phlegm)‚Ä¶

entry.title: The surprising connections between diet and mental health
entry.summary:
Fermented vegetables like kimchi are thought to bolster your mood by improving your gut microbiome. They do so by populating your gut with healthy bacteria that balance out the bad bacteria. Research shows that certain foods really can help with depression and stress. Here‚Äôs why‚Äîand which foods help most.
You‚Äôve undoubtedly heard the adage that you are what you eat. It turns out that it may apply to brain health nearly as much as physical health. Research increasingly supports the idea that eating the right foods and avoiding the wrong ones may improve your mood and emotional well-being over time.

entry.title: PSA: Never pick up a wild animal‚Äîespecially a baby wombat
entry.summary:
While wombats may appear cute and cuddly, they can be incredibly dangerous, and it's best to keep a distance from them in the wild. A video has been circulating of a woman taking a baby wombat from its mother. Here‚Äôs what experts want us to know about the dangers of interfering with wildlife, even if it seems innocuous.
Most people know not to come between a mother grizzly bear and her cubs. But what about a mother wombat and her wombatlet?
Wombats are short, squat marsupials native to Australia. And if you‚Äôve seen them in the news as of late, it‚Äôs because American tourist and social media influencer Sam Jones posted a video of herself snatching a wombat joey away from its mother. Jones proceeded to run down a dark road with the frightened creature.
